"Thanks," Amber said. "Now I just have to figure out how to explain all this to her. When I change back, it won't be all the way. Who knows what I'll look or sound like?"

"Maybe start with texting," I suggested. "Let her know as much as you're comfortable with. She will need to know what's happening to you, though. If you were to keep it secret from her, she'd want to know where her friend went, and where this guy came from."
1553321111111211112111111121112.title: The Agency steps up its game

15533211111112111121111111211121.content:
Mom's Moon card brought us all back to the S.U.B. Station. "Where day go?" Sam asked.

"We're underground, sweetie," Mrs. Vance replied. "We'll be here until things are brought somewhat back to normal."

"As normal as they get for us, anyway," I added.

"No wike," Sam said.

"We're not here because we want to be, Sam," Lyssa told him. "We're here because being up there isn't very safe right now."

"Let's pick out where we'll be living until things die down," Mr. Vance said. I was glad to see that the first spot they checked was at the opposite end of the station. I certainly did not relish the thought of living too close, in a confined space, to someone who needed his diaper changed.

The next group to arrive was Susan and her family. "Everybody OK?" her father asked.

"A few of us are shaken up," I replied, taking the opportunity to hug Susan, "but nobody's hurt. From what I've seen, we've got plenty of space."

"We'll need it," Susan said. "You know that Asian girl who just started at our school?"

"Narrow face, close-set eyes, high cheekbones, doesn't talk to anybody?"

Susan nodded. "Her name's Mindy Saotome. Dad's done some checking, and he thinks she and I might be related. Apparently, her maternal grandmother and my paternal grandfather were brother and sister."

"Not the best circumstances for a family reunion," Mr. Tanner said, "but they'll have to do."

"I'll need to think of some way to explain this to Mel and Julie," I said.

"Whatever brings them down here," Ted said. "It's a cinch the Agency will come after them, too."

I saw another group coming in. "Who's that?"

Ted looked. "Looks like the Rodgers family, and they've got somebody with them. Not to worry; we figured we'd need to accommodate a lot of people, and we've got the space."
15533211111112111121111111211121.title: The exodus to the S.U.B. Station begins

155332111111121111211111112111211.content:
"Long time no see, David." shaking Mr Rogers' hand, Ted said. "I just wish it was under better times." he then motioned to the boy. "I see you have added a new member to your family."

"This is Alex, our second born." surprising everyone, Mr Rogers said. "He has the same ability to change reality as Christina and I only he had no power over it."

"What do you mean?" concerned, Garth asked. "Was his power out of control?"

"He's likely too young to control such a power." wincing, I thought. "Poor kid."

"He has the power to literally become an added member to any family with that family never aware he was an intruder as, to them, he was always one of them." serious, Mr Rogers said. "My wife and I have the same power, we used it to infiltrate the criminal element when we helped the Problem Child Gang back in the day."

"Poor Alex was literally jumping from family to family, blacking out each time before entering and leaving." with a sad look, Mrs Rogers said. "He never had any memory of being a part of those families he visited but he remembered everything about them, now knowing why."

"That had to be maddening." wincing, Garth said.

"We managed to stabilize his power and changed reality so he was always and will always be our son." touching Alex's shoulder, Mr Rogers said. he then sighed. "The reality holding him to his family had corrupted after years of constantly jumping around, they no longer know who he is."

"That's terrible!" stunned, I said. then a thought came to me. "Wait, why don't any of us know him as always being your son, Mr Rogers?"

"Because, with your powers, you or Beth, or Caitlin would have seen through the reality change and suspected Alex as an intruder." serious, Mr Rogers said. "We exempted you and the others from the reality change so there will be no doubts that Alex is our son."

"Well, in that case, welcome to the substation, Alex." extending his hand, Garth said.

Alex smiled. "Thanks."
155332111111121111211111112111211.title: Meeting time

1553321111111211112111111121112111.content:
"We should get everyone together," Garth said. "We need to put everything we know on the table, and try to get a better picture of what we are dealing with."

"Not now," Ted answered firmly. "Tonight, when we are able to gather freely."

"Why? Where is everyone?"

"Susan Tanner is in another part of the station," Ted explained, "finishing her training with her parents. They tell me they will be finished by tonight."

"Marisol is almost done unpacking," Cait chimed in. "Trish and Brad are helping her." She added, with a smile, "I have a feeling they are going to get back together."

Mrs. Jones sighed. "Alyssa is watching over her brother, Sam, while her parents consult Beth. Her ability to communicate with spirits has increased in power, and it has her a bit shaken."

That sounded like something up a witch's alley. "My mom and I might be able to help her with that," I said. "We'll talk to her later."

Ted nodded, then turned to Alex. "Mr. Rodgers needs to be brought up to speed, so he understands what we may be facing in the near future." Turning back to the rest of us, he said, "Sarah Barns will arrive after sunset. Madame Vague has agreed to escort her here."

"Don't forget about me," Tim piped in.

"Relax, lad," said an older man who looked a little like Tim, as he ruffled the boy's hair. "No one is forgetting about you."

Ted nodded in agreement. "We'll discuss what you saw in your sketchbook with Madame Vague when she returns with Mrs. Barns and her husband. Damien, Annette, and Amadeus Johnson are getting themselves settled. We'll be talking to them later."

"What about Travis and Megan?" Garth asked, looking every bit as worried as he sounded.

"Travis Greenway and Megan Connors have gone missing," Ted replied.

When the rest of us picked our jaws up off the floor, he continued. "I have my best men looking into it, but, from what we have so far, it looks like some government agency got wind of their abilities."

I didn't like the sound of that, so I checked my Tarot cards. I didn't like the card I drew: The Devil, symbol of bad choices. I showed it to Mom, and she sighed. "Heaven help them."

"What is it?" Garth asked. "What card did you draw?"

"It's the Devil card," I replied. "Travis and Megan are with some bad company."

Hearing that, Garth turned to Cait. "Caitlin, can you find them?"

Cait lightly placed a hand to her head, while Mom drew a card from her own deck. After a pause, Cait said, "They are safe, for the moment. Though I sense they feel threatened." This was not doing wonders for Garth's self-esteem as someone who was trying to act like a team leader.

"They are with a new player," Mom said. "Someone who follows a different set of rules."

I tried to get a look at Mom's card, but she wouldn't show it, not even to me.

We all turned to each other, concerned, before Ted sighed and said,...

15533221.content:
As I was entering the dinning room to have breakfast, I gasped and froze as a short scream echoed inside my head! Mom turned to me, worried. "Talk to me, Lilith." Firmly but kindly, she said. "What are you experiencing?"

"I- I heard a scream in my head." My voice trembling, I replied. "Now, I'm hearing two voices but I can't make it out."

Mom sighed then turned to a deck of Tarot cards. I watched with growing interest as she shuffled them with one hand then threw them into the air. My first reaction was to look down at the floor but I was in for a surprise when the cards flew about on their own beforer arranging themselves as if she were reading my fortune on a table!

"Mom..." Nervous, I began.

"Hush, child." Quickly, mom scolded. "In a minute."

I watched, increasingly nervous as mom viewed the cards. "Someone is in grave danger." Finally, she said. "Two children, a boy and a girl; siblings." She turned to me, her expression dark. "Come to me, Lilith. I need to hear what they are saying."

At first, I hesitated. Only I had become morbidly curious and walked to mom's side where she moved the cards around with a wave of her hand. As she did, I began to hear the two voices more clearly. Was mom moving the cards like a dial on a radio to get a better signal? I jumped upon hearing the voices clearly. "Right there!" Instinctively, I announced. "I can hear them!"

"Tell me what you hear, Lilith." Firmly, mom said.

"The boy is Tommy and his sister is Aura." Listening, I said. "They said they are prisoners of someone called The Agency."

Mom frowned. "That is not good." Darkly, she said. "That is not good at all!"

She waved her hands and the cards flew back into a neat deck before she slammed them down onto the dinning room table. "You can forget about going to summer school, young lady!" Urgently, she said. "I'll make arrangements for you to be schooled at home!"

I had never seen this side of mom before, it was frightening. "What's going on, mom?" Wincing, i demanded. "You are scaring me..."

"I'm scared too, dear." Her face softening, mom replied. "I will explain everything in a moment but right now, I need to make a phone call." She paused, seeing me shake my head. I had always done this when I was close to going into tears.

"Please mom..." Trembling, I begged. "What is going on?"

Mom sighed. "Remember that graphic novel series you love so much, The Problem Child Gang?" Cryptically, she asked. I nodded to which she nodded back. "It's non fiction, dear. I was the mysterious girl the gang knew as Madam Vague."

I gasped at that. "What?!"

Mom ignored me, grabbing a cellphone I had not seen her use before. She dialed a number and waited for someone to answer. "Creed, this Madame Vague." Darkly, she said. "The tower as risen again. Hear me out..."
15533221.title: A dark past and an uncertain future.

155332211.content:
After completing the phone call, mom motioned me to sit at the breakfast nook in the kitchen before preparing a pot of tea. Once she had poured herself and I a cup, she joined me at the table. "Waterfront City has been a center for strange happenings for over a hundred and fifty years." Softly, she began. "All those born here develop strange abilities upon reaching their teen years; sometimes even sooner." She took a sip of her tea. "I was born here and so were you."

"Hence why I found myself floating above my bed this morning." Shaken, I said.

Mom nodded. "As you can imagine, rumors of this spread like wildfire and people came pouring into the city to investigate." Calmly, she said. "Well, it became a problem when the rich and powerful, including ours and various foreign government agencies decided to make use of our children for their own selfish ends. Action was called for."

"The problem child gang." Whispering, I said.

Mom sighed. "Each generation of freedom fighter groups had their own names." Softly, she said. "Your grandmother was known as Miss Shadow. Together, she and I helped the Problem Child Gang out of more than a few scrapes." She giggled slightly. "My mother was more hands on while I kept my distance, mostly because she did not want to see me get hurt."

"This is... Incredible!" Tearing up, I said. "I thought you and grandma didn't get along!"

"We were very close but we also knew the dangers of favoritism." Shedding tears, mom said. "There were two funeral services to honor her; one for family and one for her friends." She dabbed her eyes with a tissue. "We all agreed that it was better that way. Your great uncle Eli fell to his knees, wailing like a child in front of her casket; they were closer than anyone could imagine."

I was crying at this point. "Why wasn't I told of all this before?" Confused, I asked.

"After twenty years, we were hoping it was all behind us." Sadly, mom replied. "Only now I see we have only slowed them down and we must be ready when they strike again." She turned to me, serious. "Before I go into any further detail, I must ask if you are willing to stand at my side to help the next generation of freedom fighters." Firmly, she said. "Once you accept, you are in to the end, do you understand?"

I nodded. "I'm in."

Mom nodded back, a look of pride on her face. "Then let us begin."

"Where do we start?" Curious, I asked.

Mom smiled and replied, "We begin with..."
155332211.title: Mom explains everything.

1553322111.content:
Mom's response surprised me. "My... training?"

"We don't have a lot of time; you have just discovered your powers and already the forces of evil are at our doorstep!" Sternly, mom said. She placed a firm hand onto my shoulder. "I need you to be strong and focus completely on my teachings."

I nodded, not knowing what else to say. Mom led me to the table then produced my deck of Tarot cards with what appeared to be a slight of hand move. "First and foremost, magic is real." Serious, mom said. "However, only a select few possess the gift." She smiled slightly. "I am pleased that gift was passed on to you as well."

"So it does not go by bloodline?" Curious, I asked.

Mom shook her head. "Genetics is but a small part of it." Softly, she said. "Again, we have little time so save your questions for later, please." She handed me my deck. "Shuffle the cards while focusing one person or event."

"So the cards will tell me about that person or event?" Wincing, I asked.

"You already know how to read the cards to tell a fortune, Lilith." Calmly, mom said. "This move I am about to teach you will allow you to get an in depth report."

I raised an eyebrow to that then shuffled the cards thinking of...

15533222.content:
My name is Tim; I am a thirteen year old boy with longish sand blond hair and green eyes. I have a passion for at, especially art for comics and Magna. I snagged an under the table job interview for a new comic book company, it took a while but I managed to get back to the orphanage before curfew. Yes, I'm an orphan; I have no idea who my parents were, just that they are not coming back.

I sat down onto my bed, knowing this job was my one ticket out of this place. All there was to do was wait to see if I got the job. They had asked for a portfolio of my work, so I had shown them a lot of pictures of different super heroes from their comics I had copied. When I got back to the orphanage, a lot of the staff and other orphans asked me if I got a second interview, to see some original art work. I decided to work on that tomorrow. The orphanage was starting to close down for the night anyway.

155332221.title: In the morning

1553322212.content:
Kiera Stanley: A 17 year old British school girl who learns she has the power to create illusions as well as certain telepathic abilities, such as memory altering and mind reading. She also has a limited ability to make herself invisible to cameras. Because of this, she has remained invisible from groups that would exploit her powers for personal gain, such as Sykes' organisation and the Agency, and even wiped the memories of her existence from anyone she fought to protect or against so nobody would know she was even there. Currently working with British intelligence, who do not know who she really is or any of her powers.

Abigail Harley: 15 year old daughter of adventurer Harry Harley, she has travelled the world with him all her life learning about archaeology and working alongside him. Because of this, she has extremely keen eyesight and good attention to detail. Due to an accident during one of her father's excavations, she was imbued with the power of an apparently mystical jewel that gave her a very fast healing rate, meaning she can recover from most wounds in a matter of minutes. She is not immortal, however, and still ages the same rate as a normal human. If her injuries are severe, her body occasionally has to shut down while her brain devotes more energy to healing her wounds, which could be problematic in combat. After getting her powers, her father hears about a recently discovered archaeological find under Waterfront City in New York because of some old contacts he has there. They head for the city to see what can be found there...
1553322212.title: New Character

15533222121.content: I walked to school, like I do every morning, making sure my powers don't suddenly flare up and erase people's memories of me ever being in the school. This was the closest I could get to a normal life, having to concentrate 24 hours a day, seven days a week to make sure people don't forget who I am. My powers are linked to my emotional state. I can use them on demand, but if I get stressed or angry, they can flare up on their own. The only people who have the slightest clue who I am are British intelligence, and even they only know what they can from observing me, which, if I don't wish to be observed, is very hard to do. I looked around at the kids walking around me, chattering amongst themselves as they walked to school. I kept my thoughts away from my nerves. If I got nervous, my powers would flare up, and I wouldn't even get to school without wiping peoples memories that I attended the school at all. My name is Kiera Stanley. I'm 17 years old and I really wish that was all. Unfortunately, it isn't. A few years ago, I developed powers, I don't know why, I don't know how, it just happened. I can create illusions, extremely powerful ones that make people think they're real. I also have memory altering and memory wiping abilities. I can change people's memories and wipe their memories of me, as if they never happened. I tried the super hero thing a few times, always wiping memories of me from the minds of the bad guys. I've forgotten my real name, when I got my powers, I lost everything coming up to that point. You want super powers? You want to be a hero, and save the world? Take it from me, it's not all its cracked up to be. I'd give it all up just for the return of my memories, it's no blessing, it's a curse, if I could just get rid of it, I'd be happy. I walked into Dalkeith High School, searching for my best friend Gina.
15533222121.title: Kiera Stanley

155332221211.content:
The school was quite large. It was newly built a few years before. It had three blocks, each block had several subjects within them. Block three connected to the dining hall and the entrance to the block was the corridor connecting them. My friend Gina was sitting on a bench that ran the length of the corridor. Floor to ceiling windows were on either side of the corridor, showing the rare, clear blue skies and sun.
"Hey Gina," I said, hugging her as was the social convention among good friends "Did you get that English assignment done for Mr Dalton?"
"Yeah, I've done it," said Gina "What did you write about?"
I had written about a princess in a fairytale kingdom. It really helped with English assignments to be able to create illusions and see what it really looked like in that kingdom. It was all just my imagination, of course, but still, it did make things easier.
"I wrote a bit of fantasy," I said "You know, the generic fairytale kingdom with princess in it, but with the twist that the princess is the hero and has to save the kingdom from a dark wizard."
"That's certainly unconventional," said Gina "I'll look forward to reading it."
I hate lying to Gina about my real identity, but really, it doesn't matter if she knows or not, as at any moment, I could make her forget me, and any day, I might be called away from this school on another assignment. Besides, revealing that I work for British Intelligence could get me locked away for breaching contract. I could break out, of course, and erase anybody's memory I was ever there at all, but I like to think that I'm doing some good by working with them.
155332221211.title: Find her alone

1553322212112.content:
First period was music with Mr Sanders. He wasn't a bad teacher, his voice just sounded so boring that his class was put to sleep just by the sound of it. The only way to stay awake in his class, for me at least, was to create illusions nobody else could see and watch them while listening to him. So for some reason, I was passing his class, but just barely. Second period, I had to sit through a period of maths. I wasn't that bad at maths, but my class was really unruly, and it was hard to concentrate on anything. I've been asking for work to do at home to catch up with work that was interrupted too much. I know that it probably won't matter, I'll probably mess up and have to wipe the memories of everyone in the school before I sit the exam. Still, I wanted to do this properly, if I was going to live a normal life. After second period, we had break, fifteen minutes of talking with Gina and a few other friends. French followed break, which I excelled at, I had been on several missions to France where I had to blend in with the locals, and that required I speak fluent French. French was followed by English, where I handed in my unorthodox fairytale story. Mr Dalton was really impressed, and Gina, who read it before I handed it in, also said it was really good. I felt pride at their compliments. Even if I had a bit of a cheat with my illusory powers, I still thought of English as my favourite subject. After English was lunch. I ate in the school canteen, where the extent of school dinners was either a burger, a pizza or a vegetarian option (usually a veggie burger). I ate my burger, talked a bit with Gina, then, when lunch was over, we had PE. I usually had to slack off in PE. My secret agent training would have given me an unfair advantage if I had participated in any of the activities. The final class of the day was Information Technology, which I spent checking emails, going on Facebook and updating my stories on writing.com. I had hacked computers to get into top secret facilities, the work given in this subject wasn't challenging enough for me. After sixth period, I left to go home.

The day had been pretty uneventful, as I walked into the house I shared with my eighteen year old sister Callie. We had lived with our parents, but they were going through a rough time, they had filed for divorce, and everyday, I was kept up with the screaming at each other. So, my sister Callie had suggested I come and live with her, for a while at least, until the whole thing blew over. I walked into the living room, where Callie was sitting, and sat down on the couch next to her.
1553322212112.title: First Class

15533222121122.content:
"So, how was school?" asked Callie
"Oh, you know," I replied "Same old, same old, I have to concentrate twenty four hours a day to stop them from forgetting about me."
Callie has been a good sister to me. She seems to be immune to my powers, so the only time I can fully relax is when I'm with her.
"It can't be helped," said Callie "If there was anything I could do, to lessen the burden you've been forced to carry, I would do it."
I put my arm on her shoulder, smiling "You've already done a lot for me," I said "Just by giving me a place where I can relax, where I don't have to concentrate to tell people who I am, with you, I can just be me, without having to force myself, my very existence into people's minds, this power is driving me mad."
Callie put her arms around me. "It's all right, sis," she said "I'm here for you, I'd like to tell you that things will get better, but the truth is, I have no idea if that's true or not, I wish I could give you better reassurance, but all I can do is be here for you, no matter what."
"That's more than enough for now," I said "I really hope, in the future, you can do more for me, I hope for an end to this curse."
"Your powers are not a curse, you know, I read a news article from the US, there's a group there called the Problem Child Gang that live in Waterfront City, they've all got abilities, like yours, there was evidently a cover up, but what happened there, it was huge, I found scraps of evidence, police files, there's very little even there, I suspect that the gang have an associate in the police force there."

Callie was extremely good with computers. She could hack into any system anywhere on the planet from our house with simple, everyday technology. Her technological genius was what had gotten her on the British Secret Services radar. Although she tried to mask her presence by going through several different servers, someone in the Service was very persistent, they had traced it to our house. She really didn't want to go to them, so I offered myself up to the service. When they remember me, I'm a top agent in their organisation, when not, they forget Callie too, because she's connected to me, I've worked out how to use my curse to our advantage, I do a bit of work for the Service now and again, just in case they track down Callie again, and they leave us alone for the most part. If there's anything of note, Callie usually lets me know. That's the thing about computer traces, they can always be reversed, back to the source, Callie was one of the best hackers in the world, she traced the tracer back to the source and placed a hidden bug in the very tracer program they were using to trace her, it picked up anything of note happening in the British Secret Service, I would go to school during the week, and take assignments in the surrounding area on weekends.

"Another pet project?" I asked "You've got to stop hacking people for the fun of it, Callie, It's already gotten you in trouble, what if this Problem Child Gang traces you back here?"
Callie responds with...
15533222121122.title: She speaks first

155332221211222.content:
The doorbell rang.
"Who could that be?" asked Callie, getting up.
"I don't know," I said, joining her as she stood. At the moment, I had no friends that remembered me, nor teachers, so the only people that could be here, were either British intelligence, or someone else that'd tracked us down. Callie opened the door. There were two girls standing on the doorstep. Both wore expensive clothes and looked tired, as if they'd been awake for too long.
"Hi," said one girl "My name is Caitlin Spencer, this is my friend Megan Connors, we'd like to speak with both of you." I looked to Callie, without speaking, we agreed that these two were no immediate threat.
"Come on in," said Callie, throwing the door wide "Come into the living room, can I get you something to eat? Drink?"
"No," said the girl called Megan "We've just gotten off the plane, though, so we're quite tired, we'd just like to sit down for a minute or two, tell you why we're here."
"All right then," I said, leading them into the living room and sitting down with Callie on one of the two couches. Megan and Caitlin sat on the other couch.
"Where is it you two have come from?" asked Callie "Your accent is American, isn't it?"
"That's right," said Caitlin "We're from New York, a place called Waterfront City."

I immediately recognised the name. Callie had mentioned she had hacked into computers in that city, and found out about a group with powers like mine in that area. Which meant that these kids were a part of the Problem Child Gang.
"Why did you come all this way?" asked Callie "We don't know anybody in Waterfront City, and I don't think we have any family there."
"We traced you through your hacking into our systems," said Caitlin "Naturally, we were curious as to who had managed to hack into our computers, some of the most secure in the world."
"We traced it here," Megan put in "And we noticed an anomaly, two people lived in the house, or that's how it looked to us, but only one had ever been registered on the Census."
"I moved here recently," I said "Our parents are going through a rough time at the moment, and we thought it best if I move in with Callie until things blow over."

"Well," said Caitlin "It's not just the census records we checked..."
155332221211222.title: The doorbell rings before Callie can answer

choices: They press you for a decision now
1553322212112221.content:
"There's no record of a Kiera Stanley anywhere," said Caitlin "For most of the time, anyway, on occasion, your name shows up on a school register, but the next day, every electronic record is gone, without a trace."
"It's as if somebody is wiping every record there is of you," said Megan "Electronic and real memory."
That was a strange thing about my power. Whenever I wipe myself from everyone's memory, it also wipes every electronic copy of my name from every electronic database where it appears.
"What's that got to do with us?" asked Callie
"Nothing," said Caitlin "What we're here for is the person that hacked into our computers the other day, our resident tech genius Steve Connors suggested we take her on, because anybody who can hack into computers set up by a technomancer is brilliant."
"We also thought we'd try to solve the mystery of the girl that's invisible to all technology and is forgotten by everyone when she wants to be," Megan added "We'd like to offer both of you a place with the Problem Child Gang, we're bolstering our numbers after the battle of Waterfront City."
"May we discuss this before we make a decision?" I asked

15533222122.title: Abigail Harley/ another character

155332221221.content:
I reached the top of the hill, where my father was already checking the ground for signs of entry into the tomb. Apparently, during the times of Ancient Egypt, many of the people were afraid of the sea, except for one, an adventurer by the name of Shaggoth. With a small crew of adventurers, he sailed across the sea and the Ancient Egyptians had pronounced him dead, believing he had fallen off the edge of the world. However, he had in fact arrived at an island off the north coast of Scotland called Orkney, where he and his crew were shipwrecked during a storm.

The evidence that brought myself and my father to Orkney was found recently in the Parish churches oldest documents, which suggested that when Shaggoth died, he was buried in a hidden tomb which was also said to contain all his treasures, including the Jewel of Life, a priceless magical jewel that was supposedly able to make someone invulnerable. Not that I believed the stories, magic didn't exist after all, but as every good archaeologist knows, all legends and tales have a basis in truth. It was entirely possible that there was a tomb filled with priceless artifacts, probably not the Jewel of Life, but still something that could be sold to museums for us to make a living. My dad had gone into old Orkney records and found the place where the ship Shaggoth had taken to Orkney had been wrecked, and, using records of his lifetime, had narrowed down the location of the tomb until only one remained, a hidden door somewhere on the top of this hill.

I knelt down on the hill, looking for odd stones, areas of dead grass, anything that might lead us into the tomb.
155332221221.title: Abigail Harley

choices: I get it wrong, booby trap!
1553322212211.content:
As I examined the stone path I had been walking up, I noticed a small patch of unlocal stones off to the side of the path. There were ten in all in the standard phone pattern, but with furrows dug to either side as if there was space for more. I knelt down next to the stones and shone my torch on them. It illuminated grooves in the surface of the stone. As I examined each of the stones, I recognised Ancient Egyptian hieroglyphs. The stones were the key to the tomb. The tomb would open after I rearranged the stones into the central line in the passcode.
"Found the key," I said "Get over here, we gotta work out how to open it."
Dad followed me over to the stones. Like me, he shone his torch on the stones. What can I say? Great minds think alike.
"Now all we have to do is work out the passcode," said dad "Nice work, kid, now, we have to get this right, otherwise, we might activate a trap."
"The point of these passcode locks is to shield your tomb from enemies that might want to plunder it," I said "But Shaggoth had no Egyptian enemies to speak of, so he had no need to be inventive with his passphrase, I know what he would have chosen."
"Go ahead and enter it then," said dad "I trust you."
I quickly moved the stones around into the right pattern.
1553322212211.title: I find the tomb entrance

choices: Continue with Harry's point of view (third person)
15533222122112.content:
As I entered the hieroglyphs, there was a loud rumbling sound and the ground below us crumbled. We fell through darkness. It wasn't long until we emerged from a chute. I shot out at speed and smashed into a wall, hitting my head so hard, it knocked me unconscious. I slid down the wall ten feet, cutting myself several times on the uneven contours of the wall. I didn't feel any of it, I was unconscious. Harry landed easier than I had, having slowed himself down using his bag, he jumped out of the tube and landed on the ground without trouble. As soon as he saw the unconscious form of his daughter, he ran over to check her. Although he knew her wounds looked worse than they were, he knew that without treatment in this place, she could get infected and die. She couldn't be left there. He grunted as he lifted her up and gently dropped her over his shoulder, then continued.
It didn't take him long to find the entrance to the tomb. Gold and jewelled boxes lined shelves on the walls while in the centre of the room, was the tomb itself. As he looked upon it, a strange, green mist seemed to seep out of the sides of the coffin. It was a man, in Ancient Egyptian clothing.
"I have waited for millennia for someone to find this place," said the voice, booming "Do not look surprised, Harry Harley, you know who I am, I am Shaggoth."
"Why are you still here?" asked Harry "Why does your spirit linger here after death, and why can I see you?"
"Restless spirits cannot be seen by just anyone," agreed Shaggoth "But my spirit is tied to this existence by the Jewel of Life, therefore, I am not an ordinary restless spirit, I cannot rest until the Jewel is claimed by someone else."
"And you think I am that person?" asked Harry
"Not you," said Shaggoth "Your daughter, she must bond with the jewel, take it and give it to her."
Shaggoth waved his hand over his tomb. A compartment in the side opened, revealing an egg-sized red jewel.
"Do not touch it," said Shaggoth "The jewel can only be touched by one worthy of holding its power, unworthy will be burned."
Harry put on a glove and picked up the jewel, placing it in his daughter's bare hand. The moment the jewel touched her, the cuts and scrapes on her arms and the bump on her head healed up and as she woke up, the ghost of Shaggoth vanished.
15533222122112.title: I get it wrong, booby trap!

choices: Later on- speaking to the curator about the tomb's location
155332221221121.content:
I woke up to find that I was in an unfamiliar area. Trees surrounded me, birds sang, and I could see the hill where we had found the tomb. A few feet away, dad was setting up our two-man tent, but he dropped the poles he was holding and ran to my side as soon as he saw I was up.
"Abigail?" he asked "Abby, are you all right?"
"Yeah, fine," I said, and surprised to see that I was right. I must have suffered quite a nasty fall when I triggered that booby trap, and I'm almost certain that I cut myself on something on the way down. I looked myself over for a cut, a bruise, anything that might suggest that I had fallen, but my skin was clean, not just from recent injuries like the ones I might have gained in the fall, but completely clean, as if I had grown new skin over my entire body.
"What happened?" I asked, examining my body for something, any imperfection, but my skin was completely flawless.
"It turns out the Jewel of Life was more than just a legend," said dad "As was the legend of Shaggoth."
"You found it?" I asked "Wait, so it healed me?"
"It did more than that," said dad "It imbued you with the power to heal yourself quickly from any wound, it was also keeping the ghost of Shaggoth anchored to the world of the living, in order to leave the world, Shaggoth had to find a new host for the gem's powers, the gem chose you, Abby."
"So, I can heal from any wound?" I asked, a little sceptically.
"I'd show you," said dad "But I don't want to hurt you just to prove you can heal."
"What would it matter if I can heal?" I asked
"You could still get hurt, Abby," said dad "You can heal, but you can still feel pain and there is a limit to what you can heal, anything too major, and you may not survive."
I hugged him "I'll be careful," I said "You worry too much, I've followed you through jungles infested with poisonous snakes and spiders, and that was without being able to heal myself, I can look after myself, dad, hell, growing up with you meant I had no choice."
"I know," dad replied "You can't blame me for worrying, though, Abby, it's my job as a parent to worry about my child."
"And it's my job as a child," I replied "To remind you that I'm able to look after myself."
"We can't give the jewel to the museum," said dad "I've got it with us, but it's connected to you, I'm not sure what'll happen if we get away from it."
"I don't suppose it matters," I replied "The Jewel of Life was just a legend, nobody but us knows it exists, we were told to find the Tomb of Shaggoth, we have done so, now, we can tell the museum curator of it's location."
"First things first," said dad, and pulled out a small, spherical jewel, a little larger than a ping pong ball "You'd better keep this with you, we'll make it into a necklace when we can, but for now, just keep it with you, I can't risk you getting hurt by being too far away from it."
155332221221121.title: Abigail's pov (first person

1553322212211212.content:
After a short meeting with the museum curator, in which dad gave him the location of the tomb, we left the island, taking a boat back to mainland Scotland. For a while at least, we had no assignments, so dad had decided to send me to regular school for a few months. I had been home schooled for most of my life due to my father's lifestyle. Before we had left Orkney, Dad had gotten me a pendant with a compartment big enough to hold the jewel inside it. It was rather big and clunky, but I resolved to get used to it. I had to keep the jewel near me, as we weren't sure how far away I could be from it, as it was bounded to me.

We would be staying with a family friend, one I had never met, but I was told she was nice. She had a daughter about the same age as me, and I would be going to the same school as her for the duration of our stay. I was told her name was Gina. Her and her mother, Tina had been living alone after her dad died a few years earlier. Dad had offered to pay some of the bills for her, we made a lot of money we couldn't do anything with most of the time, after all, but she refused unless she could do something for us too. Now, Dad wanted me to have an experience of regular school, just to see if I preferred a stable life rather than trekking across the world with him, being home schooled. I had to admit, I was curious what it would be like to be a 'regular' school kid for once. Now, thanks to my experiences with the gem, I wasn't even sure I would be classed as a 'regular' person. I just hope Gina doesn't judge me for it. I'll keep it a secret from everyone else, but if I was going to be living in the same house, I couldn't keep it from Tina and Gina.

The boat docked. Dad thanked the boatman that had offered to ferry us across, and left the boat, with me following him. It would not be until a few weeks later, after we had hitchhiked inland to a small burgh in Midlothian called Dalkeith that we began to near our destination. It was a small house with a single garage in a quiet, suburban area of the town. We walked up to the door and knocked.
1553322212211212.title: Later on- leaving Orkney

choices: After dinner- Gina shows me to my room
15533222122112122.content:
A beautiful young girl opened the door. She was the same age as me, had piercing green eyes, and long red hair. I guessed this must be Gina.
"You must be Gina," said dad "I'm Harry and this is my daughter Abigail, I believe you knew we were coming?"
"Yeah," said Abigail, opening the door wide, allowing both of us to come in. The hallway of the house was small. It had stairs leading to a second floor and two doors, one leading to the kitchen, one to the living room.
"Mum!" shouted Gina, "Your friends are here."
A woman stuck her head round the kitchen door. She had similar features to Gina, but was wearing oven gloves.
"I just finished making dinner," said the woman, assumedly Tina, "Why don't you come and sit with us and eat, I made enough for everyone."
"Tina, your a lifesaver," said dad, moving closer to hug his friend "Shall we eat?"
I followed Dad, Tina and Gina into the kitchen, and sat next to Gina at the table. While dad talked with Tina about our time in Orkney, I turned to Gina.
"So," said Gina "What's travelling the world like?"
"It's not as fun as you'd think," I replied "Films like Indiana Jones play it up, and there is a bit of that when we trigger traps and whatnot, but a careful archaeologist will never be put in harms way, still, it's pretty interesting learning history as we discover it, setting foot in temples that no one but us has entered for hundreds, maybe even thousands of years, but I've never been to regular school, what's that like?"
"Not bad," said Gina "Most of the time, the teachers are cool and you can make a lot of good friends there, but there's that odd teacher that everyone hates, or takes a specific disliking to you, but on the whole, it's good fun."
"I'm looking forward to starting," I said
15533222122112122.title: Gina answers the door

choices: Later- I'm recovering from ghost training.
155332221221121222.content:
"Would you get that for me, Gina?" asked Tina.

I decided to follow Gina to the door as I had finished eating. A girl with average height and long, auburn hair stood in the doorway. She was dressed in hiking clothes and boots.

"Abigail Stanley?" asked the girl. "My name is Beth Vance, I was asked to come here by Shaggoth, the ghost that gave you the red jewel... there is a problem."

"What sort of problem?" asked Gina, a little defensively.

However, I examined the girl. She didn't seem to pose a threat, nothing I couldn't handle anyway, growing up in the Wilderness following my father around had toughened my body and mind.

"Come on in," I said.

"Gina, is there a room where we could go?" politely, Beth asked.

Gina led the two of us upstairs and into a bedroom.

"This will be yours while you stay with us," said Gina "Don't worry, we've got more room than we know what to do with."

"Thanks Gina," I replied "Leave us alone for an hour or two."

"Good luck," said Gina, closing the door behind her.

"What do you mean a spirit?" I asked, turning my attention to Beth.

"The Viking spirit within your gem, the one who died on Orkney, he wasn't the only spirit inside the gem," serious, Beth said Beth "Shaggoth told me that each time a bearer of the gem dies, their spirit becomes trapped within the gem. If they had power, that power would be granted to the next person who gains the power of the gem. However, all this power comes with a cost and a risk. Not all the spirits within the gem are good, some are evil. A few will try to possess you for different reasons, try to make you do things you don't want to do."

"Like what?" curious, I asked.

"One may try to possess you to offer his or her sword fighting skills." softly, Beth replied. "This will come in handy in a fight." she then frowned. "Others will try to possess you so to force a swap."

"A- A swap?" startled, I asked.

"You become part of the gem and they live again, as you." to my horror, Beth replied. "The gen is very powerful but all power comes with a cost."

"What can I do?" worried, I asked. "The gem is a part of me now."

Beth sighed. "Look, the power this gem could give you may be very helpful, but if the wrong spirit takes over during a fight, it could be deadly." looking at me, Beth said. "All I ask is that you allow me to help you tune out the evil spirits so they can not take you over."

"Can't you just purge them from the gem?" hopeful, I asked.

"I'm not that powerful." serious, Beth said. "This gem gives you the power and wisdom of all those who had been blessed with it in the past. The gem is not good or evil, just those who make use of it."

"What would this do to me?" I asked "If I tune out the evil spirits, I lose their power and wisdom."

"Not quite." smiling slightly, Beth said. "The good spirits will simply become dominant."

"What do you mean by that?" confused, I asked.

"In battle, they will lend you their power and knowledge, but they will not possess you outright." serious, Beth replied. "The evil spirits will still lend you their wisdom and strength but they will not be able to take control unless you allow it." she then rose a finger of warning. "Abigail, you must guard the gem, as if anyone manages to kill you, your spirit too will be trapped within the gem. If you die a natural death, the power of the gem will be broken and all the spirits will go free."

"Why can't you let all the spirits free now?" I asked "Why wait until I die?"

"It doesn't work that way!" slightly annoyed, Beth replied. "The spirits cling to the gem and to it's wielder. Even if I had the power to release them, getting rid of just one spirit will put strain on your body!" she sighed. "You wouldn't survive getting rid of all of them and then you will be one with the gem."

"I see." softly, I said.

Beth took my hand. "You have to take the good with the bad, Abigail." more calmly, she said. "I will help you tune out the spirits who are evil and help you get into contact with those who are good." she then looked me in the eye and added, "I can only hope that you will be able to use this power responsibly."

"Come on then," I said "Let's talk to some ghosts.

1553322212211212221.content:
As I concentrated, fist-shaped balls of white gas burst from the gem, flying round the room. Each of the lights seemed to go to a space in the room and expand, changing into different people wearing different clothes. Some looked like Japanese Samurai, others looked like ninjas, their faces covered by black masks. There was even one carrying a bow. I was so busy looking at these solidifying ghosts, that I didn't see the red-coloured ghost coming at me from behind. It would have possessed me, forcing me into the gem, if Beth had not noticed it, blocking it's path, she punched it to the ground.
I turned and I wasn't sure what was weirder, that Beth's fist had made contact with the incorporeal ghost, or that her impact seemed to have left a mark on the ghost.
"What's going on?" I asked
"I don't know," said Beth "This one is an evil ghost, it was going to possess you, I meant to block it, it wouldn't be able to possess me, it can only possess the holder of the gem, but it felt solid to me, nothing like a ghost should, how I've never been able to feel ghosts before."
"What should I do?" I asked "If you hadn't been here, I would have already been possessed."
"Talk to the good spirits," said Beth "They're over there, I tried to filter out the bad ones, but I guess one got lucky, I'll keep blocking the bad ones from leaving the gem."
I nodded, and walked over to the half dozen ghosts that had left the gem.
"Look," I said "I think it's cruel and unjust that all of you have been trapped in this gem for so long, I wish that I could let you go free now, but apparently, that would only force me to join you in the gem, that wouldn't help anyone, so here's the deal, we work together, you stop the evil spirits inside the gem from taking me over, and lend me your skills and knowledge when needed, and if I die a natural death, the power of the gem will be broken, and you'll all go free, how does that sound to you?"
The archer spoke "It sounds like a good deal to me," he said "I vow to protect you from being possessed by the other spirits within the gem that is our prison."
"As will I," said the ninja, pulling off the mask to reveal a female.
"I will too," said the samurai. The three spirits vanished. This left three Vikings. The leader spoke first.
"My name is Shaggoth, I was the last person to wield the gem, this is my father and grandfather, both former wielders, we were all slain in battle, so were unable to break the power of the gem, I am glad that there is finally a person who can break the curse and allow us all to go free."
"I will do what I can to make sure you do get free," I said "And if you lend me your skill in battle, I'm sure we'll be unstoppable."
"I'm sure," said the spirit of Shaggoth, as he and his kindred faded into the white spirits, flying back into the gem.
As soon as they had returned to the gem, Beth collapsed to the ground, panting.

"It's all right, Beth," I said, kneeling down on the floor next to her "They're gone, by the way, how did you connect to that ghost?"
"I don't know," she said "Like I said, that's never happened before, it's new, which worries me, last time my powers became more powerful, there was something big coming up, and I fear that now they are increasing again because something else is about to happen, something even worse than what happened before."
"Your not making much sense," I said "What happened before, and what do you think is going to happen now?"
"I guess I'll start at the beginning," said Beth "Have you ever heard of the Problem Child Gang?"

"Yes, I have," I said "I've read them all, I think I identified with them, even before these powers, I was different from everyone else, I travelled around with my dad, I guess the whole fact that I didn't have a normal life made me identify with them, who had a life, ironically, much closer to normal than I had."
"Well, this is probably going to be a little hard to believe," said Beth "But everyone in those graphic novels actually existed."

How do you respond to this?

"I've heard of the comics," I said "But I've never read them, they never published in Britain, and I travel so much, I would most likely have missed novels anyway."

"Gina?" I asked "What are you doing?"
Gina kept her guard up for a few seconds, her eyes wide with fear, then, when she realised she wasn't being threatened, relaxed.
"I didn't mean to hurt anyone," said Gina "But I was curious, I heard there were others with powers."

Gina looked startled. "How do you know?"
"I've studied a number of different languages and dialects," I replied "I had a hunch that you were talking about yourself, not me, that hunch was correct."

"We won't," promised Beth "Show us what you can do."

Gina nodded, and, pointing both arms at the ceiling, she closed her eyes. I wondered what we were looking for, when something liquid seemed to flow upwards, up her arms, forming a mould of something. Then, it turned silver. Gina had two cannons on the end of her arms.
"I've never tried to fire them," said Gina "I've been too scared of what might happen."

"She might know something," said Beth "Something that can help us work out what's happened to you."

"Go ahead then," I said "Go down and tell her, then we can leave."

Before we'd even gotten out of estate, our path was blocked by several unmarked, black cars.
"Turn around," said Beth to the Tina, who was driving "We need to go out another way."
"This is the only way out of the estate," said Tina "This is the only way we're getting out."

I followed Gina and Beth out of the car, as all three of us walked towards the blockade. I accessed my gem as I walked, allowing the energy from the spirits to flow through me as I surveyed the enemy. They all seemed to have guns, but the guns didn't seem to have ammo clips, they seemed to have what looked like batteries on them. They were stun guns, so they weren't trying to kill us, just disable us and take us in. I, again, looked through the spirits, and chose one simply called Thunderstrike. According to the memories I had accessed, he had the ability to absorb any energy damage that hit him, absorbing it to give him increased strength and durability. He could then fire this energy from his hands as beams of electrical energy. As I selected him, and his power flowed into me, and his knowledge flowed into my head, I saw Gina bring her hands up, and the two cannons appear where her hands were. A spiritual form seemed to rise up from Beth, forming into an old Amazon-looking woman holding a sword. Suddenly, three white spirits came from the gem around my neck, forming into a sword, shield, and helmet.

"How did that happen?" I asked in my head. I heard Thunderstrike's voice reply-
"We spirits are able to summon anything we had on our person when we died," he said "I thought they would be useful for this combat, no?"
"Perfect," replied, smiling as Thunderstrike guided my sword and shield into a combat-ready position.
15533222122112122212111.title: We are pursued

The men began firing beams of energy towards the three of us. I dived in front of Gina as several blasts hit me. I felt their energy flow into me as Thunderstrike ran towards the men shooting at us. I felt my body go faster than I'd ever felt it go before. It seemed the energy absorbed by Thunderstrike could also be used for increased speed. I made a mental note to ask him later what else I could do with his power. I sliced one of the men's weapons in half, knocking one on the other side to the ground with my shield, before slicing his weapon in half, too. I turned to continue fighting, as many of the men near me switched their guns for stun batons. The others continued to fire at Beth and Gina. I spun, slicing my sword through all six batons, then jumped, kicking two of my six opponents to the ground. I backed off, allowing the four that were still conscious to regroup. The car dropped them off at the edge of a private airfield with a single plane on it. Beth led us quickly towards the plane and onto it, where we were greeted by her father.
"We have to go, dad," said Beth, serious "We were attacked by members of the Agency on the road, we got through, though."

1553322212222221.content:
Hi. My name's Melissa Davenport. I just turned 14.

I suppose I'm like most girls my age, but there is one difference: I've been totally blind since I was born.

I do a pretty good job of getting around. I might do a little better, if I could get my older brother, Zach, to let me do more. I know he means well, but he doesn't seem to know what overprotective means.

High school will be a new experience for me, as Mom and Dad have decided to send me to Zach's school. It'll be my first school that doesn't have the words "For The Visually Impaired" in its name. Not that I mind. Until I get the layout memorized, I'll need to get around by holding somebody's arm. If you know a better way to get a guy's attention, I'm all ears.

I told you before that being blind was the only thing about me that was different. Well, that was true, or, at least, it used to be. One day, though, something very different happened to me.

I had decided to visit a friend of mine, Mrs. Dalrymple. She's blind, like me, but she was maybe the most independent person I knew. She was the first to really show me how much I could do. I'm not saying I'll be driving in a couple of years, but, thanks to her, I could really (if you'll pardon the expression) see myself on my own one day.

I visited Mrs. D about once a week, and, usually, she was alone when I came by. Oh, sure, she had grandkids and great-grandkids who looked in on her from time to time, but she lived alone, and liked it. I only hoped I could be half that capable when I was nearly 100. Hell, I only hoped to make it to nearly 100.

I rang the doorbell, and identified myself into the speaker. In no time, she unlocked the door and let me in. "I'm glad you came, Melissa. Would you like some tea?"

I never turned down Mrs. D's tea, because she always served it with vanilla sandwich wafers on the side. I sat on the left side of the couch, my usual spot.

Mrs. D brought out the tea, poured it into cups, and set my cup in front of me. "I'm so glad you came today, Melissa," she said. "I... I have a feeling that this may be our last visit."

"You kidding, Mrs. D?" I asked. "You'll be here when I'm a hundred."

She chuckled. "If only that were true, dear." She sat down next to me. "Lean closer, Melissa. I want to give you something." I leaned closer, and opened my mouth to ask what she wanted to give me.

Before I could say anything, though, she grabbed the back of my head and kissed me full on the lips.

I tried to pull away, but her grip on my head was too strong. I felt something in my mouth. I thought it was her tongue, until it slid down my throat.

Finally, she let go of my head, and I pulled away. "What was that?"

I didn't get an answer, because, right then, Mrs. D fell over into my lap.

"Mrs. D?"

I gently picked up her head. There was no resistance on her part. I patted her face, like you do when you want someone to wake up. But she wasn't waking up.

I put my hand over her face. She wasn't breathing.

I was glad I knew where pretty much everything in her living room was, because it made it easier for me to find her phone. I called 911.

"911, what is your emergency?"

"I'm a friend of Mrs. Dalrymple's," I said. "she passed out in my lap, and she's not breathing."
1553322212222221.title: Melissa

15533222122222211.content:
Mrs. Dalrymple's death hit me hard. At the funeral, I discovered that she had touched the lives of a lot of people in the small city of Waterfront, New York. I saw the parents of many of Zack's school friends there, including the chief of police, Ted Jones. My mother held me close during the entire funeral; she understood how close I was to Mrs D. Zack was his usual overprotective self, ready to pound anyone who said a single disrespectful word. Still, it gave me comfort to know that Mrs D had touched so many people in her lifetime.

Shortly after returning home, mom called me down to the living room. I entered to hear the voice of the chief of police, Ted Jones. "I deeply apologize for coming so soon after the funeral, Miss Davenport." Sincerely, he said. "However, I am required to ask you a few questions as you were the last person to see, err, be with her when she was alive."

"My daughter has already spoken to the police." Defending me, mom said. "Why do you feel you need to ask her more?"

"With all due respect, Mrs Davenport, your daughter is not the only person hurting." Patiently, Ted retorted. "She saved my life when I was a lot younger; I owe it to her to be as thorough as I can when investigating her death."

"You suspect foul play?" Worried, I asked.

Ted sighed. "Mrs. Dalrymple had helped a lot of people." Softly, he said. "In doing so, she made a few enemies; it is not the first time an attempt was made on her life."

I gasped at that, remembering the unknown object she had forced down my throat with that kiss. I turned to mom, pale; then turned to chief Jones. "She didn't tell me anything that led me to believe she was in any trouble." Shaken, I said.

"She never shared her troubles with others." Honestly, chief Jones said. "However, this morning, we discovered that her house had been ransacked." He sighed, looking me in the eye. "Miss Davenport, it is very important that I ask this; did Mrs Dalrymple give you anything in any way."

I gulped, causing chief Jones to frown. "She did, didn't she?"

"Chief Jones, you are frightening my daughter!" Annoyed, my mom scolded.

"The people who ransacked Mrs Dalrymple's home were after something specific!" Cryptically, chief Jones snapped. "It will not take long for them to search here for it as well!" He sighed then turned back to me, retrieving a card from his jacket pocket. "I am leaving you my card." His face softening, he said. "If you think of anything else or if anything... strange happens. Do not hesitate to call me; this is very important."

"Y... Yes, sir." Shaken, I said.

"I will assign a detail to watch your house for a few days, just to be on the safe side." Serious, chief Jones said. "Keep that card with you at all times, okay?"

I nodded and chief Jones left. As I heard him pull away in his squad car, I could not help thinking, "Mrs D... what did you make me swallow? What were you involved in?"

I slept restlessly that night, experiencing strange dreams of unfamiliar shapes and colors. I found this disturbing as I had never seen colors before. When I woke up the following day, I discovered that something strange had indeed occurred. It was as if all of my working senses had been somehow kicked into turbo mode. I could hear Zack softly snoring in his bedroom with my door closed, I could feel the vibrations of mom walking around downstairs, I could even smell mom's favorite perfume all from my bedroom.

"What's happening to me?" Shaken, I muttered.

Figuring, I must be dreaming, I moved to my window to let some air in and was bombarded with an overwhelming sensation. My mind became literally flooded with strange images of various shapes and colors! Having never seen color before, it terrified me and I screamed at the top of my lungs as I slammed the window shut. I fell to my knees, crying; I was frightened and confused by what was happening to me. I heard both mom and Zack call my name and felt the heavy vibrations of them running towards my room. Zack was first to throw my door open with mom right behind her, dragging the police officer with her.

"Sis! What's wrong?!" Startled, Zack demanded.

I looked up at Zack, not expecting to see him, only to find an image of his muscular form in various unfamiliar colors. I turned to mom and the officer and saw their forms as well in different patterns of strange colors. "Zack, mom..." Terrified and confused, I whimpered, "I... I'm scared! I... I think I'm beginning to see!"

Zack looked at me, surprised then slowly smiled. Behind her, mom teared up, looking trapped between joy and worry.
15533222122222211.title: At home after the death

155332221222222111.content:
I was rushed to the hospital where our primary family physician, Dr. Huff and her hand picked team of nurses took a look at me. Dr. Huff was 35 years old, mom's age. She was tall and slender with shoulder length black hair and blue eyes. Mom did not trust anyone else other than Dr. Huff; she told me that the two went way back and had been through a lot together.

A barrage of tests were ordered but they seemed out of the norm. I was given an eye exam where I was asked to look at a chart on a lighted panel. I was surprised that I could read every letter and number clearly, right down to the smallest digits. Then came a hearing exam, which I passed easily. After that was a strange walking test where I had to walk around a number of obstacles. Many I was able to detect, though they looked strange to me. I should have suspected as much, being blind since birth. Still, I made it through the maze. Finally, Dr Huff tested my reflexes but not as one might think. She threw random objects at me, asking me to catch them. I did so with each object with ease.

"I think we've seen enough." Serious, Dr Huff said. She turned to her nurses. "Do you all agree?"

The nurses nodded and Dr Huff excused them. After the last nurse had left, Dr Huff spoke. "Melissa, your four existing senses have become super charged in a way that gives your mind a three dimensional view of the world."

This stunned not only me but mom and Zack as well. "I... What?!" Taken back, I demanded. "How is that even possible?!"

"Mrs Dalrymple had the same condition, Melissa." Serious, Dr Huff said. "While I can't discuss the details, you seem to have developed the same adaptation. I suspected this and modified my tests to determine if that was the case."

"What do you mean, Sarah?" Worried, mom asked.

Dr Huff, known to mom as Sarah, motioned to the eye exam chart. "This is not an ordinary eye chart; the letters and numbers are cut outs over a heated light." Bemused, she explained. "Melissa was detecting the heat that moved through the shapes." She smiled. "I believe that your daughter has developed a sense of touch so acute that she can feel the heat within and around our bodies, giving her a mental image. She can see what we look like based upon our heat signatures and the movement of the air around our features."

"So she literally sees the world through her sense of touch." Mussing, Zack said. "That's pretty cool but does she have any depth perception?"

"That was just one of her four senses, Zack." Smiling, Sarah said. She then motioned to the hearing exam table. "Half of the sounds that Melissa noted she had heard were too high for normal humans to detect. Through this, she can detect how far an object is based upon how long it takes a sound to bounce off it to her, giving a fair sense of depth perception."

"You mean the echo location trick Mrs. D taught me?" Surprised, you asked.

Sarah nodded. "I was amazed when I saw her use it the first time and i asked her if she could teach it to you as I knew you were struggling with blindness."

What about the obstacle course?" Serious, mom demanded.

"That confirmed my theory." Smiling, Sarah replied. "Melissa, though still technically blind, has somehow found a way to use her existing senses to perceive the world around her." She then turned serious. "Of course, she will need training in how to use these new found abilities. It is very fortunate that Mrs. Dalrymple was also my patient; I can help her learn how to understand the images she sees."

I gave a nervous smile but stiffened as I heard Mrs Dalrymple's voice in my head. "Well, it goes a little deeper than that, deary... I'll explain later when you are alone."

To hear Mrs Dalrymple's voice in my head was creepy enough but her promise to explain later when I was alone was even more so. I bit my lip, wondering what to do...

155332221222222112.content:
The police officer excused himself. Mom asked, "What are you seeing?"

"I see you," I replied, "Zack, I saw the officer until he left, I see the window - "

"The window?"

"Yeah, the window."

Mom and Zack went to get dressed, and I started putting on my clothes. "What is happening to me?" I said aloud. "What kind of seeing is this?"

*It's not really seeing, Melissa.*

I gasped. The voice sounded exactly like -

*Your hearing is now acute enough to detect air currents flowing over things, and your brain interprets this flow as shapes. Also, your sense of ambient temperature is acute enough to detect body heat, which your brain interprets as color.*

I sat on the edge of my bed. "M-Mrs. D?"

*No, Melissa. Martha is dead. I sound like her because I lived inside her for many decades. Just as I now live inside you.*

"Wh-what are you?"

*I am a symbiotic organism that came to this planet thousands of years ago. I bond with one human at a time, giving them enhanced senses. Your senses of hearing, smell, touch, taste, temperature, and balance are now well outside the norm for your species. In return, all I ask is that you let me live in your brain, and add your knowledge to mine.*

This is too weird, I thought.

*Martha thought so, too, at first,* replied the voice. *Yes, I hear and understand your thoughts, as you hear and understand mine.*

If you were part of Mrs. D, I thought, why didn't you save her?

*I am sorry, Melissa. The human body is far more complex than my own, and I cannot add my longevity to it. All I could do was keep her alive until she and I found a suitable host.*
155332221222222112.title: continue.

1553322212222221121.content:
Once we were all dressed, we sat down for breakfast. As the whatever-it-was said, my senses told me far more about the world than I had ever imagined. I could taste everything that went into the cereal I was eating, and smell the chemicals in Zack's favorite cereal. "The Chief is here," I said.

"No, he isn't," the police officer said.

Right after he said that, there was a knock on the front door. The officer bent over at one spot on the door, then opened it. "Good morning, sir."

"Good morning, Lewis," Chief Jones said. "You can patrol the perimeter while I'm here." I could smell Chief Jones's aftershave and deodorant, and his wife's perfume. I could also smell sugar and vanilla from the plastic bag he was holding.

"Good morning, Chief Jones," Mom said.

"Good morning, Kris," he answered. "Tell me, what all is in your basement?"

"The laundry room, the furnace, and a rec room."

"We'll talk in the rec room. If you have a land line down there, disconnect it, and turn off your cell phones and tablets."

"Chief," Mom said, "yesterday, I told you you were scaring Melissa. Now you're scaring me."

"And the sort of people who cut apart Mrs. D's cane scare me."

Like mine, Mrs. D's cane was basically a few eight-inch lengths of plastic tubing with shock-cord running through them. This lets you fold it up and stick it in your pocket or purse, and then bring it to full extension with a flick of the wrist. Anyone who would cut it apart must be looking for something, and determined to find it.

As we walked down the basement stairs, Zack asked, "Anything new on the case, Chief?"

"You might not want to answer that, Ted," Mom said. "The neighbors have asked us to let them know if we hear anything about this."

"Maybe I should mention that in my next press conference," the Chief replied. "Someone might crack if they're afraid of what ordinary people might do to them."

Once we were in the rec room, Mom, Zack, and I sat in our usual spots, and the Chief stood in front of me. "First thing," he said, "Mrs. D's family has asked me to apologize if they seemed aloof at the funeral. The granddaughter and some of the great-grandkids had visited her an hour or so before you, Melissa, and she told them that she thought someone was snooping around. Thing is, they didn't really believe her, and they... let's just say, they felt pretty bad when they got the bad news. They asked me to let you know that they're glad she was with someone she knew, and who really cared about her."

I nodded. I knew, before too long, I was going to start crying.

He opened his plastic bag. "Sugar wafers? The past couple days, the stores seem to sell them as fast as they can stock them."

"Thanks." I felt like I needed a couple sugar wafers more than anything.

"Melissa, if you can, I'd like for you to tell me about that day."

"I went there, about my usual time. Mrs. D offered me tea and sugar wafers. She said she thought it would be our last visit." I could feel the tears coming. "She asked me to lean closer, so she could give me something. When I did, she kissed me, and - " I couldn't go on. I started crying for Mrs. D.

Mom put her arm around me, and Chief Jones laid a hand on my shoulder.

Eventually, I was able to pull myself together. Chief Jones said, "If you want, you can just nod or shake your head when I ask you this: Did Mrs. D give you something while she was kissing you?"

I nodded.

"Chief," Mom asked, "what is going on?"

"I don't know, Kris. And it won't do any good asking Steve. He's assigned to a different case." Steve was my dad, another officer on the force.

Chief Jones took my hands. "I don't know what Mrs. D gave you by kissing you, Melissa. But I know this, and I want the three of you to remember it to your dying day: Mrs. D could have passed it to her granddaughter, or one of the kids, but she didn't. Whatever this was, she wanted you to have it."
1553322212222221121.title: The arrival of the Chief

15533222122222211212.content:
"Chief Jones, I have a strong suspicion that there is something you are not telling us." Forceful, Zack said. "If it is something that could put us at risk, we have a right to know!"

Mom gasped. "Zack...!"

"No, no; he is right." Calmly, Chief Jones said. "There is a lot more to this but I did not speak of it because I have nothing to connect it other than a gut feeling."

"What is it?" Worried, I asked.

Chief Jones sighed. "Twenty years ago, there was a small group of kids with unique skill sets who were determined to protect this city." Serious, he explained. "They called themselves the Problem Child Gang."

"They were real?!" Shocked, I demanded.

I found myself torn between shouting in excitement and screaming in fear. Zack had told me of the graphic novels and toiled for a year to make a Braille version of them for my last birthday. My favorite character was called Miss Shadow. She was a mysterious character who walked about in all black and a black scarf around her eyes. It was obvious she was blind but her other senses allowed her to fight with the skill of a martial arts master.

"They were real." Darkly, Chief Jones confirmed. "However, their old enemies have returned and a new group of kids have risen to the challenge."

"What does this have to do with us?" Worried, mom asked.

Chief Jones bit his lip, looking uncertain. Finally, he replied, "We have reason to believe that Mrs D was the one known as Miss Shadow."

My jaw dropped. Did I hear him right?... Mrs D was the powerful Miss Shadow? I looked up at chief Jones and gasped as I noticed something different about him. His muscles are generating a ton of heat! It was as if he were deliberately holding them back! "He is deceptively strong." Amazed, I thought. Then a thought struck me and I gasped, thinking, "Oh my gosh! He was Tex the mighty!"
15533222122222211212.title: A grave situation.

155332221222222112121.content:
*You are correct, Melissa,* said the voice of the thing inside me. *When Chief Jones was young, he was Tex the Mighty of the original Problem Child Gang.*

I took several deep breaths to calm myself. "Mom, Zack," I said, "I'd like to talk to the Chief privately."

"Alright, dear," Mom said. "Come along, Zack." Zack followed Mom out the rec room door, and closed it behind him. I heard Mom walking up the stairs, but I didn't hear Zack's feet.

"What did you - " Chief Jones began, but I silenced him by raising my hand. I crept up to the door.

I could hear Zack breathing on the other side. I slowly turned the handle, then yanked the door open, sending Zack falling to the floor.

Zack picked himself up, and I assisted him by pulling him up by the shirt collar. "I said privately."

Zack left the room again. This time, I waited for him to get halfway up the stairs before I closed the door. I heard Mom say, "Serves you right for eavesdropping on your sister."

I turned to Chief Jones. "I think we'll be left alone now."

"Alright," he said. "What did you want to talk about?"

"You knew Mrs. D was Miss Shadow all along,... Tex."

He gave a nervous chuckle. "I'm sorry, Melissa, but you've - "

"Your pulse goes up when you're lying, Chief," I replied. "Mrs. D had powers, and she gave them to me. If you couldn't fool her, you shouldn't try it with me."

He sighed. "Alright. Yes, I was Tex the Mighty. What are you going to do?"

"I figured keeping that secret was important to you, Chief. That's why I sent Mom and Zack out of the room. I couldn't talk about what happened without them finding out about your childhood."

"Thank you for that. What do you want to know?"

"How much do you know about Mrs. D's powers?"

"I know she had them. I know that, even though she was blind, trying to sneak up on her was as useless as trying to sneak up on me from the front."

"Sounds like I've got big shoes to fill."

"As Chief of Police," he said, "I cannot encourage you to do such things. However, it is possible that some other young people might decide to talk to you." He got up, walked toward the rec room door, then stopped and turned to me again. "It might interest you to know that the Latin for 'problem child' is puer quaestio."

The Chief and I walked back upstairs. As he headed back to the station, my head was buzzing. There were other kids like me, who possessed powers. Kids with a connection to Chief Jones. Kids who would come to see me soon.

On the other hand, somebody had ransacked Mrs. D's house looking for something, something that, I now knew, was living inside me. It was possible that they had killed Mrs. D to get it. If that was the case, they might come looking for me, too.
155332221222222112121.title: I keep my discovery secret.

choices: Mom calls, I have a visitor.
1553322212222221121211.content:
Once I was able to get some time for myself, I decided to have a talk with the entity within me. "What should I call you?" Curious, I demanded. "Do you have a name?"

*Well, Mrs Dalrymple called me Madam West as that was the person I had inhabited before her.* Kindly, the entity replied. *You could call me Mrs D, if you like. In my world, we did not have birth names as we existed as one collective mind.*

"What brought you to Earth... Dee?" My curiosity rising, I asked. "Did something happen to your home world that forced you to move to other planets?"

*Is Dee what you chose to call me?* Giggling, Dee asked. She giggled. *Dear me, no. We did not come from a planet, we lived among the stars in space, it was our world.* She sighed. *To answer your question, it was curiosity that brought many of us to your planet. We discovered that by living inside a host body, we gain incredible longevity and our host gains incredible abilities in return.*

I was surprised to hear that the symbiont, whom I had decided to call Dee, lived among the stars and that they came to Earth out of sheer curiosity. "What can you tell me about my powers?" Again finding my voice, I asked.

*It is different for everyone, dear.* Patiently, Dee explained. *From what I can tell, your four existing senses have risen to an epic degree.* She paused then stated, *I'll try to break it down for you one sense at a time.*

"Okay." Nervous, I said. "let's start with hearing."

*Your hearing is like a radar.* Serious, Dee explained. *You give off high pitched sounds which bounce off objects and return to you, giving your mind an image of what is there. Only that is just part of it.*

"High pitched sounds?" Confused, you asked. "I don't understand."

*You are doing this without thinking, Melissa.* Kindly Dee said. *It was more than just your senses that gained power. Right now, I am simply helping you understand how to can see the world around you.*

"Then I have a radar sense like a bat." Smiling, I said. "That's pretty cool."

*Then there is your sense of touch.* Calmly, Dee said. *By feeling the subtle currents of wind and various degrees of temperature, you can make out the shape of a door or a window. Through this same sense, you can tell of a door or window is open or closed.*

"I can also sense if a door is slowly being opened or if someone is in the room." Serious, I added. "No wonder Mrs D was impossible to sneak up on."

*On top of those is your sense of smell and taste.* Serious, Dee said. *Once you get a whiff of a person or animal, you will instantly know if he or she is near by catching their scent. Also, you will be able to tell if something had been added to your favorite foods as you would know what they are supposed to smell and taste like.*

"So all of these senses give me an image of the world around me." Amazed, I muttered.

*They do far more than that, my dear.* Kindly, Dee said. *However, that is basically how you are able to see the world around you.
