"I know." Sadly, Olivia said. "She was there and soon, it will come full circle when she goes back into the past."

"What are you going to do?" Wincing, I thought.

After a pause, Olivia replied, "Pray..."

With that, her voice fell silent, making you sigh. "Olivia never forgave herself for the boy's death." Sadly, Dee said. "Todd never forgave the people with real powers in the city for not being there when a live needed saving even though he could have been that one to save him."

"Why didn't he?" Sadly, I asked.

"He froze." Softly, Dee replied.

I sighed at that. "This is a lot to take in." Tears forming, I said.
1553322212222221121211112112111211111231.title: Reader's choice

1553322212222222.content:
Lucinda Gilroy has a lot of nicknames. Most are about her height (she's only 4'10"). Some are about her lack of development compared to other girls her age. Some call her a nerd, due to her love of science fiction. Her oldest nickname may be Jinx, because, sometimes, things happen when she's around.

Lucinda is about to learn that these things don't just happen: she can make them happen.
1553322212222222.title: Someone else entirely

15533222122222221.content:
Hello. My name is Lucinda Gilroy. Unless you talk to my family, or are a teacher, you might not recognize it.

I'm only 4 foot 10 in my stocking feet, so most people call me names about height: Shrimp. Runt. When the Hobbit movies came out, a few people called me Halfling.

Or maybe you've noticed that I haven't grown out any more than I've grown up. Yes, it's true, I'm a member of the Itty Bitty Titty Committee. So some folks call me Surfboard.

I love science fiction, and I usually have a paperback under my arm (not during school hours, of course). This gets me called Nerd a lot.

I think my first nickname was Jinx. Things seemed to happen around me. Somebody might trip and fall. The school bus might break down.

It wasn't just bad stuff that happened, though. One time, Mrs. D dropped a $100 bill, and a gust of wind carried it off. Right when the bill was over my head, the wind died down, and the bill fell right into my hand. Of course, I gave it right back to her, and she was so thankful, she gave me a $20.

Then, one day, I found out what was causing it: I was.
15533222122222221.title: Lucinda

155332221222222211.content:
It happened in my room.

Mom and Dad have six kids. I'm the oldest, and, so far, the only girl (Mom says Mikey will be the last, but she's said that before), so I have my own room. If you come inside (after knocking and waiting for me to admit you), you'll find my bed in the far right corner, with my nightstand next to it. Next to the door is my closet on one side, my dresser on the other. In the near left corner is my bookcase, and, in the far left corner, my writing desk. That's where it happened.

Right in the center of my desk is my typewriter, with space on either side for paper. Clean paper goes on one side, and what I've written goes on the other. There's a beat-up copy of Writers' Digest, and two rejection slips. I've hung on to the slips because the editors added helpful notes: One told me to use a paper clip to hold my submissions together instead of staples, and the other told me that my second draft should be about 10% shorter than my first. I was reviewing my latest story for its second draft when it happened.

A lot of fantasy and science fiction writers are asked, "Where do you get your ideas?" To my way of thinking, the question is backward. Writers don't get ideas; ideas get writers. Richard Matheson wrote The Shrinking Man after he saw a movie where a guy put on a hat that was too big for him.

I was rereading my story, marking the misspellings, unnecessary words, and too-long stretches, when it occurred to me: I didn't know where this story came from.

It was a short story about a girl who finds out she's host to an alien being. It seemed like a good story to me. But, try as I might, I couldn't think of why this story occurred to me. "Where did I get this idea?" I asked myself.

*I gave it to you.*

I looked around. Who said that?

*It seemed like an ideal way to introduce myself.*

I swallowed hard. "Wh-who's there? Where are you?"

*I am a symbiont from another world. I am inside you.*
155332221222222211.title: Lucinda's story

choices: There's a knock on my bedroom door
1553322212222222111.content:
I swallowed. "Inside me? How did you get there?"

*I have always been inside you, Lucinda,* the symbiont replied. *It is the way of my race. We dwell inside native beings, and give them certain talents in return.*

"So, you gave me my writing ability?"

*No, Lucinda. That ability is purely yours.* The symbiont paused. *I gave you the ability to alter probabilities around you.*

I was already sitting, but I felt like I needed to sit down anyway. "Alter probabilities?"

*Yes, Lucinda. Remember all the strange things that have happened when you were around? You were tapping into your powers.*

"I really am a jinx?"

*If that word helps you to understand, then yes.*

"Why me?"

*As I said, Lucinda, I have always been inside you. It had to be you, because it was me, too.*
1553322212222222111.title: My symbiont

choices: Learning more about Owen's new self
15533222122222221111.content:
While I tried to cope with this, someone knocked on my door. "Who is it?"

"It's Owen." Owen is nearly twelve, the oldest of my younger brothers. "Can I come in?"

My brothers didn't usually come looking for me, so I was curious. "Okay."

Owen came in, closing the door behind him. "Am I interrupting anything?"

"No," I lied. I wasn't anywhere near ready to start talking to anybody about the alien living inside me. "What's on your mind?"

"There's... something I want to show you," he said, as he sat on my bed.

"Okay, so, show me."

He bowed his head, and the weirdest thing I'd ever seen happened.

Owen's hair grew longer before my eyes. His shirt, which had been white with red sleeves with the words BOYS RULE! written on it, changed to white with pink sleeves with GIRL POWER! written on it.

Owen lifted his head, and his face now looked girlish. "How do I look?" he asked, his voice a lot more feminine.

"Owen," I said, "you... you look like a girl."

He smiled. "That's because I am a girl,... when I want to be, that is."

It was a good thing I was sitting already, because I would have been looking for a chair otherwise. "You... you can turn into a girl? When did this start?"

"Two weeks ago," she said. "I woke up in the middle of the night, and went to use the bathroom. You can imagine my surprise when I saw this in the mirror."

"And you're totally a girl?"

She nodded and lifted her shirt, revealing a training bra. "This is why I wear undershirts now. Trust me, I need this."

"I don't understand... How does this happen?"

She shrugged. "Search me. It freaked me out at first. But, as I learned to control it, I'm okay with being a part-time girl. What do you think? Wanna hang out with your new sister?"
15533222122222221111.title: There's a knock on my bedroom door

choices: Talk to the chief of police.
155332221222222211112.content:
"Why did you decide to tell me now?" Curious, I asked.

"Grandma talked me into it." Bemused, Owen replied. "She knows a lot about happened to me and apparently what happened to you."

This caught me off guard. "Wh- What are you talking about?"

Another knock came to the door before grandma, who i called 'mum' peered into the room, smiling. She was short and stout with slat and pepper hair tied into a neat bun and gentle blue eyes. She smiled at Owen and me through her half moon glasses. "Do you mind if I join you girls?" Kindly, she asked.

I nodded and mum walked in wearing her favorite black dress. She sat down and looked at me with a kind smile on her face. "I see you have discovered your symbiont." Softly, she said. "Owen came to me, freaked out when he, or rather, she discovered her own abilities."

"Mum, you're scaring me." Wincing, I said. "Where did these symbionts come from? Does Owen have one inside of him, err her?"

"The symbionts have been here in this little town since the early eighteen hundreds, my dear." Smiling, mum replied. "They came here along with an alien craft that crashed here around the same time."

"An alien craft?!" Turning pale, I demanded. "The symbionts are aliens?!"

"Deep breaths, Lucinda." Kindly, mum said. "Don't faint on me."

"The ship that crashed here was a derelict; a ghost ship." Softly, Owen said. "Drifting through space for hundreds of years after the crew had abandoned ship. The symbionts were using it to move from one planet to another in their quest to explore."

"How do you know that?" Wide eyed, I demanded.

"It's one of Owen's abilities as a girl." Calmly, mum explained. "Everyone and everything she comes into contact with she will very quickly know everything about as if she had known the person or worked with the object all her life." She giggled at my stunned expression. "You, on the other hand have the ability to tip the odds for everything in your favor."

"Hashtag lottery win." Grinning, Owen said.

"It doesn't work that way; I tried." Bemused, mum said.

"You have the same ability?!" Surprised, I asked.

Mum nodded. "That's how I knew you had the granddaughter of my symbiont."

I was completely floored by this but also intrigued. "Does Owen have a symbiont?"

"Owen was affected by the alien ghost ship." Softly, mum replied. "In fact, everyone born in this city after eighteen hundred and thirty five has developed incredible powers and abilities."

I could not believe my ears. I quickly picked up a copy of the Problem child Gang graphic novel to which mum giggled before sighing. "I remember those kids." Bemused, she said. "They drove me and the other members of the police force nuts."

"So they really existed." My head spinning, I said.

Mum nodded. "I was the police commissioner at the time." Serious, she said. "I was the leader of a separate group whom the town secretly called the clean up crew. We worked hard to make certain too much attention did not fall upon our town."

"The Problem Child Gang, as they called themselves, found it necessary to have a strong force to protect the city so its inhabitants were not forced to show their hand." Calmly, Owen added. "It was a noble idea and effort only..."

"Please allow me to tell the story, dear." Lightly scolding, mum said. "Or would you rather talk about how you learned to act like a girl?"

I giggled at that, imagining the struggle for a boy to learn how to act feminine. Owen blushed as well before saying, "Please continue."

Mum smiled then continued. "As Owen said, it was a noble effort on their part only they got more and more confident in their abilities with each victory." Somewhat sadly she said. "Looking back, I should have told them what Sykes was really after."

"Sykes, the immortal thief." Remembering the story, I said. "What was he really after?"

"The alien technology." Startling me, mum said. "Sykes is one of the few who was blessed and cursed with immortality; he was there when the ship crashed into the Oceanside cliff."

"Now there is a new Problem Child Gang." Worried, I said.

Mum nodded. "Which is why I need you and Owen on the new clean up crew." Serious, she said. "What do you say, Lucinda? I've been itching to come out of retirement; want to help Owen and I save the city again?"

"Well, what do we do first?" Curious, I asked.

Mum smiled at me gratefully. "first, we..."
155332221222222211112.title: Reader's choice

1553322212222222111121.content:
"... need to have a chat with the chief of police," Mum said . "He'll be of great help to us."

" Just a minute, " Owen said. She closed her eyes and became a boy again. "I'm not ready to tell the folks that I have superpowers, but only when I turn into a girl."



Mum drove us to the police station, and led us through the building to the chief's office. The secretary recognized her immediately. "Good afternoon, Madame Commissioner."

"The title is unnecessary," Mum said . "Is his nibs busy?"

"No, ma'am. Would you like me to announce you?"

"I've never been one to stand on ceremony." She walked straight into the office, with us in tow.

Chief Jones stood up when we came in. "Good afternoon, Mrs. Krensky," he said. "To what do I owe the pleasure?"

"A matter of old business, Ted," Mum said . "You're aware, of course, that there's a new Problem Child Gang?"

"Of course."

"And I may assume that a new Guard is not far away?"

"A reasonable assumption."

"Then we'll need a new Clean-Up Crew, as well. That's why I'm here, Chief. Do you know of any young people who aren't attached to one or the other?"

He smiled. "As a matter of fact, I do."

He picked up his phone and called a number. "Honey, come down to the station, would you? And bring Hope."

As he hung up, Mum asked, "Who's Hope?"

"My daughter."

"I thought your daughter's name was Grace."

"This is a different daughter," he replied. "It's a long story."
1553322212222222111121.title: Talk to the chief of police.

15533222122222221111211.content:
Ten minutes later, two young girls who looked no older than fifteen or sixteen entered Ted's office. Both were tall and slender only one had light brown hair and green eyes while the other had honey blond hair and fire hazel eyes. "Hey, Grace." Smiling, I said to the brown haired girl. "Long time no see; is this Hope?"

The girl giggled. "Grace is my daughter but I do thank you for the compliment." Surprising me, she said. "Also, yes; this is the newest member of our family, Hope Jones."

"Mrs. Jones has not aged a single day since her symbiont granted her powers." Softly, mum explained. "She could easily pass as a high school or young college student, if she so wished."

Mrs Jones blushed slightly at that. "Let's stay on the subject, please." Serious, she said. "Ted told me that you want to reactivate the clean up crew."

"Someone has to keep a lid on the shenanigans of the new Problem Child Gang." Grinning, mum said. "At least 'Tex the mighty' has a better idea of how difficult that job can be."

Chief Jones blushed slightly. "To be young and foolish again." Smiling slightly, he said. "Still, Heather is right; we need to stay on topic here. Are you planning to lead the new group after you retire this month?"

"Mum, you're retiring?!" Surprised, I asked.

"Well, I am getting up there in age." Blushing herself, mum replied. "However, there is one part of my abilities I never mentioned."

Chief Jones raised an eyebrow while Mrs Jones smiled before turning to me, "We called your grandmother 'the great infiltrator'." Bemused, she explained. "She called herself..."

It was then chief Jones smiled and finished, "Shaman."

Mum giggled before quickly shrinking down to my size! She now had doll like features and long raven hair; the black dress shrinking to match her new size! "With me, age is relevant, dear." Bemused, she said. "It is a different form of immortality; this is my fifth trip through the ages."

I nearly fainted, falling back into a chair. "This is a tad bit too much for me." Overwhelmed, I said.

"Tell me about it." Pale faced, Hope said. "I thought my head was going to explode when they brought me up to date."

"There is a lot to cover, kids." Serious, Chief Jones said. "I'll have someone bring up some hot chocolate and coffee along with a few snacks. If we are going to do this, we are going to do it right this time."

Mum nodded. "I agree." She then turned to me. "It would be inappropriate for you to call me 'mum' in this form, Lucinda. Just call me Tracey."

"That's going to be awkward." Wincing, I said.

Mum, or rather, Tracey giggled. "Just wait until we tell your mom."
15533222122222221111211.title: Meeting Hope

155332221222222211112111.content:
Chief Jones's secretary brought us the hot chocolate and snacks. As she left, I said, "Hope, the Chief said it was a long story how you came to be his daughter. what's so complicated?"

Hope hesitated a little. "I... wasn't born the way most people are," she said. "I was grown in an artificial womb, at the CHILD facility outside of town."

"Really?" Owen asked.

Hope nodded. "One of the people who worked there helped me to escape. From him, I learned that I was created from the DNA of two of CHILD's enemies: Chief Jones and Ina Dalrymple."

"Mrs. D?" I asked.

"The very same," Chief Jones said.

"But she was so old!" Owen said.

"She wasn't always an old woman," Tracey replied. "And she was an enemy of CHILD longer than most of the people in this room have been alive."

"Tracey," I asked, "why don't more people in town have powers, if we all have symbionts?"

"Not all of us recognize our gifts for what they are," she explained. "Some people think that they're just very good at their chosen fields."

That made sense to me. After all, when I first found out about my symbiont, I thought it was responsible for my writing ability. It only made sense that some people would reach the opposite conclusion.

"Also," Tracey continued, "not everyone who learns of their powers necessarily likes them. I think your father is one of these. And some people receive powers that either are of no use, or are only practical under certain circumstances. Your mother's like that."

"What can she do?"

"She has a second set of teeth."

"I've never seen them," Chief Jones said.

"You haven't looked in the right place."

I think it took us all about the same amount of time to get the picture, and we all had the same reaction.
155332221222222211112111.title: The meeting begins.

choices: watch the footage of the hit.
1553322212222222111121111.content:
"They're not where you are thinking." Bemused, Tracey said. "Her extra set of teeth are in the place of her fingernails; they come out like a cat's claws."

"So mom's hands are literally extra mouths?" Disturbed, I asked.

Tracey nodded. "She hated that unusual power though it had its benefits." Serious, she said. "Her sense of taste was impressively acute; she could name all of the ingredients in anything she tasted or touched with her two extra mouths. She could also speak literally any language, including the language of animals due to the nature of her extra mouths and vocal chords."

"Talking to animals might be cool." Smiling slightly, I said.

Tracey chuckled. "Your mother didn't think so." Smiling, she said. "She did not want to be known as the real 'Dr. Doolittle'."

"The point is, even though everyone born in this town has special abilities from various sources, not everyone sees themselves as more than an ordinary person." Serious, chief Jones said. "We do not ask anyone to join any of the defending groups unless they first show an interest or we see the potential of them helping any group in a positive manner."

"No one is forced to join." Calmly, Tracey added. "The idea is to keep this secret safe from the rest of the world. CHILD is one of the few threats to that secret."

"Who are they, exactly?" Curious, Hope demanded.

"They are a secret group of special powered individuals with interests in the most talented of our townsfolk." Serious, chief Jones replied. "We do not know where they came from or who pulls the strings at the top but we do know that they pose a threat to our town and our people."

"Did the Problem Child Gang fight CHILD?" Curious, Owen asked.

"We locked horns on occasion." Frowning, chief Jones replied. "Do not go looking for them and do not engage them alone if you are confronted by them. They will not hesitate to kill anyone who gets in their way."

"I don't understand." Worried, Hope said. "How did these people get their own special powers?"

"Our town was not the only place an alien ship crashed, my dear." Surprising us, Tracey replied. "CHILD has managed to repair one of those ships and uses it as their flying headquarters."

I turned pale at that, which chief Jones noticed and motioned to the hot chocolate. "There is a lot to cover so I suggest you take a second to compose yourself, Lucinda." Gently, he said. "Someone is trying to take out the old members of the Problem Child Gang and make certain the new group does not get too far off the ground."

Tracey nodded. "We need to find out who and why so we can deal with it."

Owen and I nodded, understanding the situation a little better. "Where do we start?"

Chief Jones rose from his seat. "We start by looking into the video footage of the hit the other day, see if we can find some clues." Calmly, he said. He then sighed, seeing my confused expression. "We made contact with an old enemy who seemed to want to talk; it turned out to be a trap set to take our lives. The new problem child gang thwarted their effort."

"There were a number of unusual crimes in the weeks before the hit." Serious, Tracey said. "We may find some clues there as well."

"Maybe Hope saw or heard something before her escape that might help." Looking at the chief's daughter, Owen said. "Even the most insignificant thing could hold volumes of clues."

I sat there, hearing the options, wondering if there was anything I could think of to help.

Eventually, the little group decided to...
1553322212222222111121111.title: More of the meeting

15533222122222221111211113.content:
Hope pulled out some papers. Indicating the first one, she said, "This was left out for me on the day I decided to escape CHILD. At first, I didn't read much beyond the names of my biological parents. But, once I settled in in my new home, I did."

She paused. "Because of how I came into the world, I don't have a symbiont. Their plan was to implant one when they decided I was ready, and use me to kill their enemies. Including my father."

Chief Jones put a hand on her shoulder, and Hope put her hand on his. "I'm okay, Dad." Indicating the other papers, she said, "I've been drawing maps of the places in CHILD where I was allowed to go. I know that there are others there. I don't know if they were created like I was, or if CHILD took them from somewhere else. I really want to go back there, and rescue as many as possible."

"A sensible objective," Tracey said. "I'll draw up some plans in the next week, the kids can learn about their powers, and perhaps we can be ready to strike after I fake my death."

"Fake your death?" Owen and I asked at the same moment.

"I have to explain where your grandmother went, now, don't I?" she replied. "If the retired police commissioner were to simply disappear, my affairs wouldn't be put in order for another seven years. But, if everyone believes I am dead, then my will goes into effect. Your family will get my house, and my pension will relieve some financial matters." Turning to Owen, she said, "My house is larger than the one you're currently staying in. I can't promise you your own room, Owen, but I'm sure you won't be sharing with all five of your brothers." Turning to me, she asked, "Do you think you can learn to share a room with your 'cousin,', Tracey?"

"I never minded having my own room," I said. Then, with a smile, I added, "I think I can get used to having a roommate."
15533222122222221111211113.title: Question Hope.

155332221222222211112111132.content:
With this first meeting of the new clean-up crew over, Tracey changed back into Mum and drove Owen and me home.

Mom was not happy when we arrived. "Glad to see the two of you are still alive," she said. "Mind telling me where you were? And why you didn't bother to leave a note saying where you went?"

"I'm sorry, Mom," I said. "You're right, we should have left a note. Mum was... telling us a few things."

"Things like what?"

In answer, I took Mom's hands. I paused a moment to look at Mom's fingernails. Before, I had thought she just liked white nail polish. Now, I knew that was the color of tooth enamel.

I turned her hands over, and soon was the line in each palm that indicated her extra mouths. I kissed each one, then placed them on my cheeks. I soon felt her tongues touching my face.

Mom was quiet for a while, then said, "Y-you know?"

"We know. And it's time you and Dad knew about us, and what we can do, and what we'll be doing soon."
155332221222222211112111132.title: At home

1553322212222222111121111321.content:
"How much did your grandmother tell you about me?" Mom asked.

"She said you could talk to animals," I replied, "and you didn't want to be known as another Dr. Doolittle."

" There's a little more to it than that, " Mom said. "I can talk to animals, but they don't always have much to say. I once asked a dog to tell me what it could about a burglar, but all it could tell me was that it was a man with gas. Not much for the police to go on."

About then, Dad came home. "What's going on?"

" My mother told the kids about my little talent. "

"We've got abilities of our own," I added. "I can later probabilities."

" And I can tell you anything about whatever I'm looking at, " Owen said. "But it only works if I change into a girl first."

Dad was shocked. "You can change into a girl?"

Owen nodded, then demonstrated.

"Amazing," Dad said. "I could turn into a girl, but I could never get used to it. I felt like I looked too much like my sister." Dad had talked about his older sister before, and how she died when he was young.

"Mum told us that the Problem Child Gang isn't just a comic book, that they were real people," I said. "And now, there's a new Problem Child Gang operating. Which means they'll need a new Clean-Up Crew to pick up after them. Which is where Owen and I come in. We'll be trained by Mum. But, first, she needs to fake her death, and resurface as our cousin Tracy."
1553322212222222111121111321.title: Revealing all

15533222122222222.content: Kaylee Newman is frustrated in her efforts to shed 30 pounds. She hasn't seen anything yet.
15533222122222222.title: Someone else

155332221222222221.content:
I'm Kaylee Newman, and this is my story.

About six months ago, I noticed I was starting to put on weight. Mom told me it was no big deal, that hardly anyone noticed, but I was gaining five pounds a week and couldn't think of why.

When I got to 30 pounds over my usual weight, my doctor put me on a diet and exercise plan. I didn't lose an ounce. So she put me on another plan. Same results.

If there's anything worse than getting fat for no reason, it's staying fat for no reason.

After six months of work, all I'd lost was six months. I stood in front of a full-length mirror, looking with disgust at my double chin, my belly, my muffin top. Suddenly, I felt a tingle all over.

When the tingling stopped, I was astonished to see myself getting bigger. Rounder. Fatter.

I couldn't believe my eyes. It was like watching a balloon from the Macy's parade being inflated, only I was the balloon, and I wasn't full of helium, but fat.

When it finally stopped, I was almost unrecognizable. I was big enough to make six of the old me, with some left over.

How could this happen? I knew you couldn't lose weight overnight, believe me, I knew. But you also can't gain hundreds of pounds in less than a minute.
155332221222222221.title: Kaylee

1553322212222222211.content:
This can't be happening, I told myself. There's just no way I became so fat that I can't go out my bedroom door. I closed my eyes for a minute.

When I opened them again, I was my old self. Well, my 30-pounds-overweight self. But that was better than being nearly half a ton. It must have been a dream.

Granted, I thought I was awake the whole time, and I was certainly standing when it happened, but I figured it was a dream. Like the time I dreamed the doctor gave me a double cheeseburger and a banana split. Exhausted from whatever had just happened, I crawled into bed and fell asleep.



I had another dream. This time, I was out in a park, when I spontaneously gained weight again. I looked around, expecting the kids around me to start making fun of me for being 800 pounds. But they didn't.

They didn't make fun of me. In fact, they seemed to expect it. "Ready?" one boy asked, as his body swelled with muscles.

"As I'll ever be," I replied.

"Let's do this!"



I woke up before I could figure out what we were supposed to do, one muscular boy and one incredibly obese girl. But at least I knew it had been a dream.
1553322212222222211.title: Remain calm

15533222122222222111.content:
The next morning, I went to the kitchen in my bathrobe. My moms were there, making breakfast. Their names are Meredith Kay Bateman and Allison Lee Newman. Meredith is a family practitioner, and Allison is a professor at the community college. "Good morning, sweetie," Allison said. "How'd you sleep?"

"I had this weird standing-up dream," I said. "I blew up to nearly half a ton in under a minute."

"Oh, honey," Meredith said, stroking her five months pregnant belly, "I wish you wouldn't worry so much about your weight. It isn't healthy for a girl your age."

"She does what she can, Mer," Allison replied. "But the patriarchy has devoted centuries to making women feel uncomfortable in their own bodies. We've done everything we can, but she leaves the apartment every day, and has to deal with people who still repeat the same lies."

"Anyway," Meredith said, "you are just fine, and you'll be a terrific big sister."

"Thanks," I said, wincing inwardly at the adjective."I'll have my usual."

"One plain oatmeal, coming up," Allison said.

I was about to sit down when I felt a peculiar tingle. It seemed familiar somehow...

I soon realized why, as my body swelled up again. The seams and sash of my bathrobe strained, then came apart, under the strain of me suddenly gaining all that weight.

I looked up at my moms. Their jaws had dropped. There was no denying it this time, this was really happening!

When I finally stopped expanding, it was all I could to to stand there naked and fat. Finally, I forced myself to speak. "M... Mom?"
15533222122222222111.title: Gaining weight again

155332221222222221112.content:
Allison came running. "Oh, my baby," she said, trying to wrap her arms around me, and failing. "What's happening?"

"I've never seen anything like this," Meredith said. "How do you feel, Kaylee?"

I didn't know how to answer. I didn't want to be this big, certainly. But I wasn't in any pain. In fact, physically, I felt... good.

The teakettle had been used to heat up the water for my oatmeal, and it started whistling. Meredith ran over to take it off the heat. She over-corrected, sending boiling water all over her arm, and she screamed.

I ran to her, faster than I would have thought someone as fat as I was could even hope to do. As I took her scalded arm, I felt some kind of force flowing out of me and into Meredith.

When the energy flow had stopped, Meredith said, "My arm."

Allison came over. "How bad is it?"

"It isn't," Meredith replied. "It feels... healed. As if Kaylee had healed me."

Allison spent a minute looking back and forth between Meredith and me. Finally, she went over to where she kept her purse, and took out an old-style cell phone, one I'd never seen before.

She dialed a number, then said, "Sherlock, it's Valor. I am answering the call of the Guard. We need to talk about my Kaylee."
155332221222222221112.title: More than meets the eye

choices: Ask why she was called Valor.
1553322212222222211121.content:
What seemed like only a second later, there was a knock at the door. Mom quickly answered and ushered a middle aged man into the room where I was standing. The man was tall and visibly muscular wearing a long brown trench coat over a pair of black pants and black shirt. I blushed horribly as I was naked and looked down at the man with my eyes begging. "Help me..." Lips trembling, I pleaded.

"As you can see, Sherlock, my daughter has discovered her gift." Softly, mom said.

"You call this a gift?!" Distraught, I asked. "This is a nightmare!"

The man looked up at me and smiled kindly. "Take a breath, child." Lightly scolding, he said. "Panicking will not help you." He produced a quarter from his pocket before allowing it to fall to the floor in front of me. "Pick up the quarter, if you please."

"Are you serious?!" Annoyed, I demanded. "How do you expect me to..."

"Don't think about it, just do it!" Snapping, the man barked.

I jumped, startled by the man's shouting command and leaned down to pick up the quarter though I had no idea how I was going to pull it off. To my great shock and amazement, I easily picked up the quarter1 Looking about, I saw that I was not only back to my normal height but I was now just as skinny as any other regular girl! I turned to the man who was again smiling kindly at me. "You see... you can do it." Calmly, he said.

"What happened?" Confused, I asked.

"You have the same power as your father who is currently doing business in Europe." Serious Sherlock said. "You have the ability to expand yourself into massive proportions." he sighed. "However, you lack any training in how to use it and that is dangerous."

"Dangerous?" Gulping, I asked.

Sherlock shook his head before turning to mom. "Show her the training video then get her ready." Darkly, he ordered. "There is no telling when they will make their next move."

I was now seriously confused, not to mention frustrated as I had already returned to my usual overweight size. "What video? Get ready for what?"

Sherlock grunted. "Have you ever read the graphic novel, The Problem Child Gang?" Cryptically, he asked. I nodded. "Who was your favorite character?"

I blinked before replying, "Freak; he was a member of the Guard." You smiled slightly. "He was a lot like me, overweight. Only he was fast and could grow into a giant of a man, seriously giving bad guys a scare."

Mom held back a giggle as Sherlock nodded, a bemused smile on his face. "That's your father." Smiling, mom said. "He is with the Cloaked Dagger, the European version of the problem child gang, helping them against The Agency."

It was a lot for me to take in. "The graphic novel series I had been reading, it was all real...?"

Mom nodded. "We were all hoping this was over and behind us." Somewhat sadly, she said. "Only our old enemies have returned and we must be ready for anything."

Sherlock sighed. "Show her the training film." Walking to the door, he said. "I will pick her up tomorrow morning at seven sharp." He gave mom a stern look. "Have her ready, Valor. She needs to be trained and it would not hurt you to go with her."

With that, the man left. Mom huffed, shaking her head before turning to me. I was dumbfounded by all that had happened. All I could think to do was...
1553322212222222211121.title: The Guard

choices: The video showed mom as a teenager.
The video showed a teenaged Sherlock.
15533222122222222111214.content:
"Mom, I have so many questions right now..." Wincing, I said.

Mom sighed before pulling out a set of clothing from the laundry basket. "Get dressed then come to the family room." Serious, she said. "We have a lot to cover and very little time." She sighed before adding, "It's a good thing you slept in because you won't get much sleep tonight."

With that, mom left the room. Confused and shaken, I quickly got dressed and walked into the family room where mom had set up a large assortment of snacks and drinks. "What is all this?" Curious, I asked. "Is the video seriously long?"

"It's about an hour long." Serious, mom said. "The discussion we will have later I fear will go well into the night." She sighed, shaking her head. "Have a seat; I will explain everything after the video as I have no doubt you will have a lot more questions than you have now."

Sighing, I sat down as mom started the video. It was basically a documentary about select members of the group known as The Guard. "There are twelve videos in all." Surprising me, mom said. "this one focuses on your father, Sherlock and myself."

I watched the video in shock and awe as I watched dad, as an overweight teenager, grow into a muscular giant before shattering a hole through a concrete wall with a single punch! He then shrank into a slender teenager and lifted a large weight before throwing it several feet!"

"Your father had the power to grow and shrink." Calmly, mom explained. "The only draw back was that he could never maintain a slender form for long as it took enormous amounts of calories to power his ability." She then smiled at me. "Your weight issue is your body preparing for that power to come to the surface."

I nodded, still in a state of awe and shock. As I continued to watch the video, I witnessed my dad fire a powerful beam of energy from his hands like in some anime fight scene! Mom sighed at that before pausing the video. "That is what Sherlock was referring to when he said your lack of training is dangerous." Softly, she said. "Your father had the ability to convert his large mass into energy and use it as a ranged weapon."

I gulped at that as mom continued the video and I saw the energy beam literally blow a hole through a car! It was frightening to think I had such abilities when my greatest worry before this was simply to lose some weight.
15533222122222222111214.title: Your choice.

155332221222222221112141.content:
The video soon showed a teenage girl I recognized as Mom. She swelled to enormous proportions, like Dad, except that, in her case, she gained muscles. The two of them squared off. First, she tried to pick him up. At first, he wouldn't budge at all. Then, to my amazement, the ground beneath Dad's feet started coming up with him.

"Your dad is one tough customer," Mom said.

Next, Mom got behind Dad, and tried to stop him from going forward. It didn't work. All she could do was slow him down.

Giving in, Mom said, "Nice work, Larry."

"You didn't do so bad, yourself," Dad replied. "I've gotta eat, now."

As Dad started eating, Mom went up to a younger version of the man she called Sherlock. "Is Larry seeing anybody?" she asked.

"I don't think so," Sherlock replied. "But there are two reasons you shouldn't pursue a relationship with him."

"Oh?"

"He's gay, and you're a lesbian."

"What? Why would... What makes you... " Mom shook her head. "You and your intuitive reasoning. You won't tell anybody, will you?"

"I'll respect your wishes."

I swallowed, though I didn't know why. "Intuitive reasoning?"

"I can make accurate deductions based on insufficient evidence," Sherlock replied.

The camera went back to Dad. "He sure eats a lot, doesn't he?"

"He needs to," Mom explained. "If he doesn't set aside time to eat, he'll gorge himself the next time he sees food."

I was skeptical, and it must have shown on my face. "Just look at yourself," Mom said.

I looked down, and my eyes almost popped out of my head.

My lap was full of Twinkie wrappers and empty bags of chips and Cheetos. My hands were orange from Cheetos dust.

"You've been eating almost nonstop since you sat down."
155332221222222221112141.title: The video showed mom as a teenager.

155332221222222222.content: Jamal Franklin is called Stretch because of his height (already over 6 feet tall at age 14) and thin build. The nickname is more apt than people realize...
155332221222222222.title: Someone else

1553322212222222221.content:
My name's Jamal Franklin.

I'm real easy to pick out in a crowd, especially a crowd of kids my age: I'm the only one my age who's more than six feet tall. Yeah, I play basketball. How perceptive of you, he said sarcastically.

My folks aren't near as tall as I am, but that might be because I'm adopted. I met my birth mom once: She said she was 13 when she had me, and unconscious when she got pregnant, so I can't really blame her for giving me up for adoption.

I'd have to say I'm pretty lucky to be living in Waterfront. Our police chief, Ted Jones, doesn't go in for a militarized look for cops, he trains them in de-escalation, and favors what he calls "good old-fashioned police work," which he says means cops help folks out if they're not busy with something else. So you're more likely to see a cop help some old lady with her groceries than add a hashtag to somebody's name. Keeps a lot of kids out of trouble, too: nobody wants a cop to say to them, "Do I need to tell your folks about this?"

The day It happened, I was heading home from a pick-up game at the park. I waved to people I knew across the street, said hi to people on my side, and checked out the girls wherever they were. No catcalling, though. My mom didn't raise me that way, and guaranteed she'd find out by the time I got home.

Old Lady Jenkins was leaning out her window, talking to one of her friends on the street. When she went back in, she bumped this flowerpot she had on the sill, and it started to fall. She loved that flower, and the pot it was in, and I knew she'd be heartbroken if anything happened to it. Without thinking, I put my hand up. I caught the flowerpot, and put it back up where it belonged.

I walked a few more steps when what just happened struck me: sure, I had caught Old Lady Jenkins's flowerpot and put it back with one hand, but her window was way up on the third floor, and I was street-level. How did my arm get long enough to do that?
1553322212222222221.title: Jamal

1553322212222222222.content: Violet McBride is almost painfully shy. She's about to discover a way to be beneath people's notice and still get attention.
1553322212222222222.title: Someone else

choices: I grow back to normal size
15533222122222222221.content:
My name is Violet McBride.

I'm the only child of a single mother. Before it all started, I didn't know anything about my father. I never saw him. I didn't know his name, what he looked like, or why he and Mom weren't together. Any time somebody asked Mom about him, she'd just start crying.

I suppose that's part of why I didn't have any friends. If nobody came over, they wouldn't ask Mom the questions that made her cry.



When my life changed, it began with a dream.

I dreamed that Mom was having a party in the apartment, and, as usual, I was keeping away from it. Then, I began to shrink.

I was dwindling rapidly. I ran to Mom for help. By the time I'd gone from my room down the hall to the living room, I was down to maybe a foot tall. By the time I found Mom, I was less than a third of that. I tried to call to her, but my voice was too high and weak to make it up as far as her ears.

I was down to a couple of inches tall when I realized that something could still hear me: our cat.

This was not good news, as the cat didn't recognize the shrunken me as human. She thought I was a funny-looking mouse. And she ate mice.

I ran as hard as I could, but I also had to avoid all the enormous feet of the people at the party. And I was still shrinking. In no time, the cat had me cornered. In desperation, I threw up my hands and closed my eyes against the coming slaughter.

When I opened my eyes again, there was no party. I was in bed.

I breathed a sigh of relief. Just a dream.

But when I looked over to where the clock should have been, I saw... more of the bed.

My dream had partially come true. I was only a foot tall.
15533222122222222221.title: Violet

155332221222222222211.content:
I couldn't believe it. How could I have shrunk like this? I walked to the edge of the bed and climbed down to the floor.

Once on the floor, I took a good look at myself. Same number of moles, same body shape. The only difference was that I was now four and a half feet smaller than when I went to bed.

Suddenly, my stomach grumbled. It was so loud that I almost expected Mom to come in, asking what that noise was.

And, just as suddenly, I was back to my full height. And I was hungrier than I'd ever been. I got dressed and headed for the kitchen.

Mom was making pancakes. "Morning, sweetie," she said. Then, motioning to the giant stack of pancakes, she said, "I overdid it a bit on the pancakes. Hope you're hungry."

"Famished," I replied. I felt like I could have eaten all of them.

Mom sat down and drank her coffee. "Where does this appetite come from?"

"I dunno," I said, after swallowing a mouthful. "There was something weird this morning, though. I was smaller."

Mom dropped her cup of coffee. Like a shot, I grabbed the paper towels and helped her clean up.

When I sat back down and started eating again, Mom said, "Smaller?"

"Yeah, I was just a foot tall. Then I felt hungry, and I grew back to normal." I saw the look she was giving me. "It's the truth, Mom, honest. Just look at my pj's, they're buttoned up, 'cause I shrank out of them."

"It's not that I don't believe you, Violet," Mom said. "It's just... I didn't expect to hear this." She gave a long sigh, and said, "We did it, Wyatt."

"Who's Wyatt?"

"Your father."
155332221222222222211.title: I grow back to normal size

1553322212222222222111.content:
Mom talked as I ate.

"Before you were born," she said, "I worked for some people as a research scientist. Wyatt was one of my coworkers. We hit it off quickly, and we felt a certain... attraction. However, our employers disliked fraternization, and strongly discouraged anyone from getting involved with a fellow employee.

"One day, we were working on a means to miniaturize matter, when there was an accident. Wyatt seemed alright for a while. After a while, however, it became clear that he was shrinking.

"Nothing we tried could reverse the shrinking process, or even slow it down. He was down to about four and a half feet when he suggested that we act on our feelings while we still could. I agreed. We slipped into a stairwell and made love for the first and last time.

"As he dwindled ever further, it reached the point where he could actually watch himself becoming smaller. He asked me to drug him, so that he wouldn't have to see this awful thing happening to him. I did it.

"28 hours and 48 minutes after the accident, Wyatt was no more. He had shrunken out of existence. Whatever was left of him fell between the atoms of a plastic enclosure.

"I quit the place after the accident. When I found out I was pregnant, my friends said I picked a bad time to quit, but I disagreed." She brushed my cheek. "I didn't want what happened to Wyatt to happen to me, and leave you all alone in the world, Violet."

She took a swig of coffee. "That's why I break down and cry when people bring Wyatt up. He never had a decent funeral. How could he, when there wasn't a body? And we can't claim any inheritance you might have coming, since the police get curious when someone claims to be the last to see a missing person. Not to mention, our former bosses might get curious about you, young lady. Moreso, if what you say is true. If you can really shrink yourself, they may decide to come looking for you. They'll want to find out how you do it, and if they can put it to practical use. There's no telling what they'd do to you, if they found out you were between them and what they want to know."
1553322212222222222111.title: My father's story

choices: Mom reads the note from dad.
There is a stranger in the house!
15533222122222222221111.content:
Later that day, I decided to practice using my gift; try to learn how to control it so it would not one day start to control me. I started simple by only shrinking down a few feet. I was five foot seven; when I stopped shrinking, I was three foot even. With my doll like features and fair skin, I looked like a two year old wearing her older sister's clothes. I could not help giggle at my reflection.

"I'm going to have to learn how to make my clothing shrink with me next time." Amused, I said. "Otherwise, I'll return to normal without attire." After a thought, I added, "Better not let mom see me like this, she might diaper me as a punishment for shrinking to this size."

I blushed at the thought and decided to try to grow back to my normal size only something went wrong. I kept shrinking! I tried to cry out for help only I shrank so fast that I could not get enough air to scream out anything that could be heard! Before I knew it, I was pushing my way through a jungle of the fibers of my carpet! "What am I going to do now?" Crying, I asked myself.

"Just calm down." Startling me, a voice replied. "There is a time limit on shrinking."

I whipped around to find myself facing a man in makeshift clothing made out of lint and sandals made out of splinters of wood! He was, by my perspective, a foot taller than me with brown eyes, scruffy black hair, mustache, and beard. At first, I was frightened only I took a second look and gasped! "Daddy?!"

The man, my dad, nodded. "It's an honor to finally meet you, kiddo." Smiling, he said. "It took me ten years to track your mother down." He chuckled. "It's a really big world out there at my current tiny height."

"You said there was a time limit." Wincing, I said. "Why did you never come back to mom?"

"She can't possibly detect me at this height, kiddo." Serious, dad explained. "I am slowly returning to normal but because I shrank so far, it would be a deadly shock to my system if I grew back to my normal height too quickly." He sighed. "It's like returning from a very deep dive, you need to decompress otherwise..."

I slowly nodded, understanding what dad was trying to say. "It's great to finally meet you." Hugging him, I said. "Only I don't understand. How did you survive?"

"Apparently, at this height and smaller, I am completely invulnerable to harm." Smiling, dad said. "Since, you obviously have the same power, I'd say you have the same invulnerability." He then turned serious. "You can't let anyone know you have this power or that you saw me. There are people out there who would kill anyone in their way to obtain what you have."

"I can't even tell mom?" Worried, I asked.

Dad was silent for a moment then handed me a piece of folded paper. "Take this with you when you return to normal." Softly, he said. "She will recognize my handwriting."

"A note?" Curious, I asked.

"A personal note." Patiently, dad said. "So don't you read it." He then grinned. "Do and I'll take you over my knee when you shrink again."

I smiled at that. Dad definitely had a similar sense of humor as mom. "Can you tell me how to grow back to normal size?" Hopeful, I asked.

Dad chuckled. "Just think big." Smiling, dad replied. "If it helps, come up with a word that makes you think of big things and a word that makes you think of small things. That's how I came back from the microcosmic world."

I gasped. "You visited a microcosmic world?!"

"A talk for another time." Serious, dad said. "You better get back before mom misses you."

I nodded and thought of a word that made me think big. I chose the word, 'Mountain' and it worked; I steadily grew back to normal size. Upon returning to my normal height, I looked down at the note and found that it had grew with me. Only my clothing was on the floor at me feet. Blushing brightly, I quickly redressed myself and hurried out with the note in hand to find mom.
15533222122222222221111.title: An experiment and revolation.

155332221222222222211111.content:
Mom was getting ready for work when I found her. "Mom, I've got something for you." I handed her Dad's note.

As she took it, she said, "What could it possibly - " She stopped talking when she saw the handwriting. "Where did you get this?"

"My room," I replied. "He's living in the carpet right now."

Mom read the note with tears in her eyes. "Where is he now? Can I talk to him?"

"Not just yet. He says it takes time for him to grow. He said something about a microcosmic world; I guess that's where he went when he shrank."

Mom hugged me, harder than she'd ever done before. "If I didn't have this note, I'd never believe it. Have you read it?"

I shook my head. "He said it's private, and he'd punish me if I read it."

A slight smile crossed Mom's lips. "It's certainly intimate. Maybe when you're older. How did you find it, and him?"

"I wanted to try shrinking myself deliberately. It's going to take some practice, especially so I can stay dressed when I do it. If I hadn't been so happy to see him, I'd be mortified that the first time I laid eyes on my father, I was naked."

"Well, when you see him, tell him I said 'Welcome home.' And tell him I can't wait to see him again." Mom wiped away the tears, fixed her makeup, and left for work.
155332221222222222211111.title: Mom reads the note from dad.

1553322212222222222111112.content:
Seeing mom so happy gave you a bright outlook on the day. It was only a week into summer vacation and you had the entire apartment to yourself. You wondered what you should do to occupy your time. Part of you wanted to hang out at the mall with your friends while another wanted to go see dad again, clothed this time.

"The note grew with me." Thoughtful, you said. "I wonder if that makes a difference."

You thought back to the note and realized you were thinking how important it was for mom to get it. There was no telling if that made a difference but you tried to shrink while thinking of your clothes and found it did not make a difference. "What am I missing?" Frustrated, you muttered. "Was it because I was holding it so tightly?"

After a moment of further thought, you decided to try another experiment. You hurried to your room and rummaged through your clothes until you found your old dancing leotard. It was like a black one piece swimsuit with long sleeves and a short skirt. You undressed and slipped it on, wincing as you felt it hugging your body like a second skin. The leotard was not tight but wearing it made you feel as if you weren't wearing anything at all. Once you had it on, you tried to shrink again and sighed as the leotard shrank with you. "At least now, I can shrink without losing my clothes though I would want to get something better to wear."

A loud crash alerted you to something wrong. You peered out of your room to see someone breaking into your apartment! He was tall with short blond hair. It was a tall man in blue jeans and a black shirt with a brown jacket. The man's face seemed to have been carved from stone with cold calculating green eyes and short black hair. You gulped seeing him retrieve a sidearm from under his jacket. Your first instinct was to lock the door to your bedroom and call the police. Only, instead, you shrank to two feet making it impossible to reach the doorknob. "Oh crap..."

The man walked towards your bed room and pushed the door open to see you. A smile cracked on his lips. "Hey, there, cutie." Kindly, he said. "Is your older sister at home? Or were you left here with a baby sitter?"

Your mouth half opened in surprise. The man thought you were a toddler girl; it made sense as when you shrank to two feet the first time, you saw one in the mirror. You gave a coo, holding up your hands, hoping to get the man to come closer so you could take him by surprise. The man did come closer, obviously suspecting nothing. When he was close enough, you returned yourself to normal, clocking him in the jaw as you grew. The man stumbled in surprise and you managed to pull the gun from his hand. "Who are you?!" Angry, you demanded.

The man chuckled. "So, Grace spawned a daughter with powers just like her father." Grinning, he said. "How interesting. I am John Stalker and I am here to talk to your mother."

"She's not home." Hissing, you said.

John smiled then, to your surprise, ripped the gun out of your hands and pointed it directly at your heart! "I'm not here to play games, little lady." Coldly, he said. "Tell your mother that there is a new calling of the Guard." He scowled. "Feel fortunate that I'm on your side for the moment."

He then viciously slapped me, sending me to the floor before walking out.
1553322212222222222111112.title: Calling of the Guard.

choices: The chief of police pays a visit.
15533222122222222221111121.content:
With my hands shaking, I called the police. A few tense moments later, a young man answered. "Waterfront police department; detective Steve Davenport speaking."

"My name is Violet McBride." Crying, I said. "My house had been invaded!"

"Help is on the way, Miss McBride." Calmly, Steve said. "Is the intruder still in the house? Are you in a safe location?"

"The intruder left; he called himself John Stalker." Still crying, I replied. "He hit me pretty hard; he said he was here to give my mom a message... something about a calling of the guard."

There was a pause before Steve spoke again. There was a dark tone in his voice, one that frightened me more. "Listen to me very carefully, Miss McBride." Serious, he said. "No matter where you are in your house, get out now!"

Terrified, I ran out of my bedroom with my cellphone still in hand. I had just fled from the front door when a loud boom shook the ground followed by a sheering heat at my back! I was thrown forwards, landing hard onto my front lawn! Painfully, I turned to see my house engulfed in flames; I had just barely managed to escape with my life! Only I knew that dad was still in the house, living inside the carpet and I screamed out for him.

"Easy, princess." A low voice said. "I hopped onto you when you returned to normal size the first time we met. You really need to clean your ears better, young lady."

I sighed at that, relieved that dad was still alive. I heard Steve calling my name through the cellphone and quickly answered. "I- I made it out." Tearfully, I said. "I'm hurt, though. My back..."

"Stay where you are, Miss McBride." Serious, Steve said. "An ambulance and police are on their way to you now. We will inform your mother what had happened."

I began to cry again after ending the call, seeing my house burning to the ground. Firefighters and paramedics arrived a minute later and I was put onto a stretcher as mom's car came screaming to a halt in the driveway.

Later, at the hospital...
15533222122222222221111121.title: I call the police.

155332221222222222211111211.content:
Later, at the hospital, the doctors determined that I had second degree burns on forty percent of my back due to the blast along with numerous splinters and a slight concussion. Mom ran into my room the instant she was allowed to visit me.

"Oh, honey, I'm so glad you weren't seriously hurt!" Tearfully, mom said, hugging me. "I am so sorry you got dragged into this!"

"Mom, who was that man?" Frightened, I demanded. "Why did he blow up our house?"

"It's a long story, honey." Wincing, mom said. "When I was your age, I was a part of a group known as The Guard."

"What is The Guard?" Curious, I asked.

"It was a part of the Problem Child Gang." Startling me, a deep voice replied.

I turned to see the chief of police, Ted Jones enter my room. "The problem child gang was real?!" Stunned, I demanded. "I thought it was just a story!"

"It was real." Serious, chief Jones said. "This was the second major attack on the original members this week." He turned to mom "I have ordered all members to be on high alert."

"You were a part of the original group?" Surprised, I asked.

Chief Jones nodded. "I was but we need to focus on the crisis at hand." He pulled out a notebook and a pen. "Do you feel up to answering some questions?"

I nodded and Chief Jones began to ask me the usual questions I had heard in any police story on television but he also asked some rather unusual questions such as 'Did you smell anything odd this morning?' and 'Were there any unusual events such as the lights flickering or objects moving on their own?' I was very puzzled by these questions so I had to ask. "Why such strange questions, chief Jones?"

Chief Jones frowned. "We had enemies with abilities of their own." Softly, he said. "We have learned how to detect them." He cleared his throat then turned to mom. "You might as well fill her in; our old enemies have returned and we fear that they are looking for revenge."

Mom nodded as chief Jones continued with his strange questioning for a short time before leaving; posting an armed guard outside my hospital room. "Mom, what's going on?" Wincing, I demanded. "I'm scared."

Mom sighed. "I once called myself Sleuth." Softly, she explained. "I had a natural talent for finding the smallest of clues and analyzing them without any equipment. I was a living forensics lab and I helped the Problem Child Gang solve many cases." She paused, holding back tears before continuing. "I stayed behind to help a group known as the Guard when a good number of the group left for Europe in hopes to stop Sykes and his followers once and for all."

"What happened?" Worried, I asked.

"We grew up." Serious, mom replied. "I managed to get a job with a government agency known as the Central Headquarters of Intelligence, Logistics and Defense, or CHILD. They too had attempted to give the town of Waterfront grief. I figured that working on the inside, I could keep their focus away from our beloved city."

I was hanging on every word, listening to mom's story. It was quite the shock to learn that my favorite story was real and I was now literally now living it...
155332221222222222211111211.title: The chief of police pays a visit.

1553322212222222222111112112.content:
I felt a sudden shift on my right side, as if something had come off me. When I looked, I saw a speck that began to grow...

Chief Jones noticed it, too. "What is that?"

"You'll see," I replied.

Soon, what had been just a speck grew into a recognizable human shape, although he was still much smaller than anyone else had ever seen. "Wyatt?" Mom asked.

I nodded. "We'll need to find him something to wear."

Mom scooped Dad into her hand and took him into the bathroom. Chief Jones asked, "That's your father?"

"That's him. He was shrunken in a lab accident at CHILD. Mom was sure he was dead, but he managed to survive. He spent a long time being sub-atomic."

Chief Jones excused himself and stepped outside. When he returned, he was carrying a hospital gown like the one I was wearing. He knocked on the bathroom door. "Sleuth? I've got a gown for your friend."

The door opened just wide enough for Mom to reach out and grab the gown, then it closed again. "What's going on, Chief?"

"I, uh, think your mother and father - "

"Eww! I mean, why are these people coming back now? And why did they try to kill me? I didn't do anything to them."

"Waterfront City has been a magnet for weirdness for over 150 years. Some people want to control it, and, when they're thwarted, have no compunctions about hurting innocent people."
1553322212222222222111112112.title: Dad returns to normal height.

15533222122222222221111121122.content:
Later on, dad was put into a bed in the same room as I with a curtain separating us. He and mom had a long talk before mom grabbed her purse and pulled out a cellphone. Only it was not the one she usually used "Tex, it's Sleuth." Softly, she said. "We are in agreement; we are answering the call of the Guard."

I gulped hearing that but remained silent until the guard announced that I had visitors. Before I could utter a word, mom signaled to allow them in. Chief Jones and his family walked in with Detective Davenport and his family following. I recognized the teenagers as Garth and Grace Jones and Melissa Davenport, who lived down the street from me. Only I did not recognize the girl next to her. As if sensing my confusion, Melissa said, "My brother transformed into a teenage girl just like Alyssa Vance; we're calling her Luana."

"As I said, strange things have been happening in this city for over a hundred and fifty years." Serious, chief Jones explained. "Right now, our old enemies have returned and are obviously working up to something big seeing how they are trying to take us all out." He sighed. "We are going to need help on this one. No one will judge any of you if you decide to back out but keep in mind that once you are in, there is no turning back."

Lu gulped. "What are you trying to tell us, chief Jones?" Nervous, he demanded.

Chief Jones sighed. "The Problem Child Gang was a real group, as was The Guard." Darkly, he explained. "We fought against real dangerous criminals who wished to do our fair city and its citizens harm."

"For a time, we thought we had defeated them." Jumping in, detective Davenport said. "We were wrong and are now forced to pass the torch onto the next generation of freedom fighters."

"However, the new problem child gang is young and inexperienced as we were in the beginning and will need help; not only from the original members but from the Guard." Firmly but kindly, Mrs Jones said. "No single group can fight a battle on two fronts easily, allies are needed in these uncertain times."

"It will be dangerous work; you will be placing your lives on the line." Serious, Mrs Davenport added. "The people you face will not show restraint because you are teenagers or even children, they will kill you if they get the chance because you stand in their way."

"Only you have an advantage that we did not." Smiling slightly, chief Jones said. "You have the police department on your side; something we really couldn't count on in our days."

"Why can't the police handle this threat?" Wincing, Lu asked.

"Not without it becoming public." Serious, detective Davenport replied. "We must tread lightly here; if word gets out of what goes on in this town... again, trouble will come in spades."

"All of the attacks thus far focus around one man, John Stalker." With a hint of anger, chief Jones said. "We are working on that as we speak but we need an ally."

"Grace and I have banded a few friends together to form the new problem child gang." Serious, Garth said. "We are getting things put together for ourselves but we can use all the help we can get before whatever these people are planning goes down."

Melissa turned to Lu who knotted her jaws before nodding. "We can't let those who blew up Violet's house get away with it." Softly, she said. "Mrs D and Mr Mist would make them pay."

Melissa looked around the room, as if to listen before stating, "Call me Miss Silhouette."

"Mirage." Pointing at herself, Lu said.

Mrs Davenport sighed before pointing at herself. "Lady Fade."

"Lady Fade?" Giggling, Melissa asked.

"Hey, I was a teenager!" Defending herself, Mrs Davenport said. "I couldn't think of anything else that fit."

"We'll have to get you a more updated 'username'." Smiling, Melissa said.

"You will need more members." Serious, chief Jones said. "I know a few people but we will have to work quickly."

"What will you call yourself, dear?" Curious, mom asked.

I paused, thinking then shrugged. "I'm not sure."

Mom smiled. "We'll think of something.
15533222122222222221111121122.title: More strange visitors

15533222122222222222.content: Developing powers can be strange enough. Imagine waking up and finding yourself in a different time...
15533222122222222222.title: Someone else

155332221222222222221.content:
My name is Josiah Higgins. I have lived all my life in Higginsport. In fact, it was for my ancestor that Higginsport and I were both named. Eventually, both names would be changed. But I'm getting ahead of myself.

It was decided when I was quite young that I would marry Elspeth Connors. While I found Elspeth charming enough, I was truly attracted to Ina Mist, but Father would have none of that. Besides her being a girl of lower class, she was blind, indecent (walking about wearing trousers at all times), and impudent. (Another reason, though Father would not admit it to anyone, was that he had suffered some economic reversals, and needed the Connors money to forestall efforts by a man named Spencer to take over the town.) Nonetheless, I fancied her. All of this became unimportant, however, when the Strangeness began.

It began when a blazing light fell from the sky, striking near a small lake often used for swimming and fishing. Reverend Simmes said it was a rebellious angel thrown from Heaven. Few took him seriously at the time, but opinions changed when the children of Higginsport began to change.

The first was the Spottiswoode boy. He went swimming after the fireball struck, and surfaced with gills. Then, Elspeth had some problems with her upper back, which were explained one day when feathered wings sprouted forth from there.

Even I was touched by the Strangeness, as I began to glow. Nobody noticed anything in the light of day, but I was brighter than a candle after darkness fell. It was how Elspeth found me. She had been flying nearby, and saw my light from my window. She invited me to come with her. Out of curiosity, I agreed.

Elspeth took me in her arms and carried me to the ravine, where other Higginsport children had gathered. There, we saw a mysterious woman in a porcelain mask. The woman waved to Elspeth. "You're later than usual," she said.

"I've brought someone to join us," Elspeth explained. "He gives forth light."

I was puzzled why this needed to be pointed out, but the masked woman said, "If our Guardian Angel vouchsafes for you, friend, then you are most welcome. I am Miss Shadow."

Now I knew why she had to be told about my light. This Miss Shadow was Ina Mist!

She explained why we had all been summoned. Reverend Simmes, thoroughly convinced that what was happening in Higginsport was of demonic origin, had summoned witch-hunters to protect the community, and to destroy those children who were now different from the norm. "I do not know precisely what is happening here," she said, "but it hardly seems demonic, as I'm sure you all agree. But if the adults will not stand up for us, then we must stand for ourselves."

And so we began the struggle to protect us and those like us from destruction. During this fight, I learned that Elspeth truly would not be the ideal wife for me. Even if I had been attracted to her and not Ina, she was more strongly attracted to another girl in our company, none other than Faith Simmes, the reverend's own daughter.

One day, during a respite from battle, I decided to explore Haunted Cave, some twenty miles from Higginsport. With my luminosity, which I had greatly mastered, its darkness would be dispelled for me, and I could see what held so much terror for so many. So I entered the mouth of the cave and descended into its depths.

Far into its recesses, I found a peculiar structure. It was entirely made of metal, and it seemed less like something that had entered the cave than something that the mountain had surrounded. Finding an opening, I dared to enter, not even going back for my hat when it fell from my head.

Walking around the place, I found a small niche in the wall, about the right size for a person. I climbed inside, and instantly regretted it, for some transparent barrier slid into place from above, sealing me inside. Once this barrier was in place, a strange mist began to fill the niche. I struggled to free myself, but I could not. Moreover, I began to grow drowsy, each breath bringing me closer to sleep. I had just enough time to connect how I felt with the mist before I fell asleep.



When I awoke, the barrier was gone. I felt as if I'd taken a too-long nap. I was certain that I'd get a hiding when I got back home.

I found my way back out of the structure. I remembered that I'd lost my hat before I went inside, but it was not there. I groaned, certain that Father would tell me to cut two or three switches from the birch tree before meeting him behind the woodshed.

I climbed back up to the mouth of the cave, remembered to douse my light, and stepped outside.

There, gathered around a fire,I saw three people: a man, a woman, and a girl. All three wore short trousers, garments I'd only seen young boys wear before. They also wore peculiar shoes. I couldn't imagine how they could be shined.

The girl noticed me first. "That's some weird spelunking gear he's got on," she said.

The adults turned to see. "Looks more like he's dressed for a wedding," the woman said.

I was stunned. They thought my clothes were strange? How could this be? "I beg your pardon," I said, "could you help me get back to Higginsport?"

The girl wrinkled her nose. "Higginsport? Where's that?"

"You know where it is, Rachel," the man said. "You just never heard it called that. Higginsport is what Waterfront City used to be called." Turning back to me, he said, "Where'd you learn to call it that?"

I staggered. "Used to be? Hasn't it always been Higginsport?"

The man shook his head. "Not for 150 years."
155332221222222222221.title: Josiah Higgins, circa 1852

1553322212222222222211.content:
"150... years?" My legs felt weak.

The man jumped to his feet and helped me to sit. "Get me a water bottle," he said.

The girl he called Rachel opened a strange-looking box, reached inside, and brought the man a bottle, which he opened and handed to me.

It was certainly shaped like a bottle, but it was made of something I'd never seen before. The liquid inside tasted like water, and the paper label said it was water. But I'd never heard of anyone putting water in a bottle. Clearly, I was in a far different world than when I had gone into the cave.

"Let's try to figure out what's going on," the man said. "Who are you?"

"I am Josiah Higgins. My family founded Higginsport."

"Okay," he said, "now for a bigger question: What year was it when you went into the cave?"

"1852. I gather this is a different year."

He nodded "It's 2017. 150 years ago, the Higgins family went bankrupt, and a consortium took over the town, renaming it Waterfront City."

I nodded. "My father has - had hopes that I would marry well, to ensure our fortune."

"How did you spend all these years in a cave, unchanged?" asked the woman.

"I found a structure of some sort," I explained. "Inside it, I wandered into something which closed when I entered. I fell asleep, and awoke here and now."

"What could have caused that?" Rachel asked.

"I couldn't begin to speculate," said the man. "We'd need to go back into the cave to find out, and I'd rather not do that. There's no telling what we could bump into."

"I'm thinking we should get our friend checked out," said the woman. "Do you feel up to walking again?"

I nodded. "At the least, I can make it as far as your carriage."

I followed them. When we arrived at a clearing near the road, I said, "I've never seen a carriage like that. But someone has stolen your horses!"

"No horses," the man said. "It's called a car. We still refer to horsepower, though."

We climbed into the "car," as he called it, and he drove it, at speeds I could not begin to imagine.
1553322212222222222211.title: What's happening?

15533222122222222222111.content:
"We should probably introduce ourselves," the man said as he drove the car. "I'm Bob Maxwell. This is my wife, Rita. And your seatmate, back there, is our daughter, Penelope."

"And I do not want to be called Penny," she added. "Once we get you in front of a TV, you'll understand why."

"Delighted," I said. "Where are we going?"

"We're taking you to a hospital," Mr. Maxwell answered. "Just to make sure you're okay."

When we arrived at the hospital, I was stunned. I had never seen a building so tall. "How many flights will we have to walk up?" I asked.

"None at all," Mrs. Maxwell replied. "We'll take an elevator."

I was checked in, with the Maxwells explaining that they found me abandoned in the forest.

A nurse came, and administered what she called tests. She drew a small quantity of blood from my arm, then handed me a cup. When I looked quizzically at it, she explained, "You need to urinate into it," and left.

"I'm not familiar with the plumbing situation in 1852," Mr. Maxwell said. "Do you need the bathroom explained?"

"Only the best houses had lavatories," I answered. "Of course we had one."

My confidence evaporated, however, when we arrived at the bathroom door. "What is that?"

"It's a doorknob," Mr. Maxwell said. "Just give it a turn, and pull."

The bathroom itself was interesting, as I had never seen a urinal before, and I was intrigued by the absence of a tank overhead. But the doorknob was more amazing by far.
15533222122222222222111.title: Getting to know the 21st century

155332221222222222222.content: Tommy Rivers has a secret. He's about to learn he has another one...
155332221222222222222.title: Someone else

1553322212222222222221.content:
My name's Tommy Rivers. I was one of the star athletes in junior high, and things are looking up for me when I start high school in the fall.

But there is something about me that a lot of folks don't know: I'm gay.

One morning, shortly after I graduated junior high, my parents announced that they'd be going out of town for a couple of days, on business, and they were trusting me with the house. "Don't do anything I wouldn't do," Mom said as they left.

"I won't," I promised. I meant it, too: I was reasonably certain that Mom slept with boys she liked when she was a teenager.

As soon as I was certain that they were well and truly gone, I called Jack. "The 'rents are away for the weekend," I told him.

"Alright," he replied, "I'll be over soon. Pick out some video games and movies for us."

"Count on it."

It wasn't much of a milestone for us. Jack and I had already had sex for the first time last weekend. But you don't often get the house to yourself for an entire weekend. For two teens still in the closet, it's kind of a big deal. I picked out some games and put them on my bed, then set out some movies on the coffee table.

When Jack came over, we greeted each other the way we usually did, acting like best friends until we closed the door behind us, then kissing. "What games ya got?" he asked.

"I figured we'd start off with Call of Duty," I answered, "then Ghost Recon."

"Grab some Cokes," he said, racing up the stairs, "and get ready to lose." I didn't mind the teasing. I knew I could beat Jack at sports, if I wanted to.

I got the Cokes out of the fridge and headed upstairs, when I felt a strange chill. I wasn't sure where it was coming from. Shrugging it off, I went to my room.

Jack was loading the game as I walked in. He kissed me. "Damn, Tommy," he said, "your lips are freezing."

"Oh, really? Guess you'll have to do something to warm them up." I handed him a Coke.

He took the bottle, then asked, "Where'd you keep this?"

"The fridge, why?"

"It's frozen solid."

I looked again. As he said, it looked as if it had spent the night in the freezer. I looked at mine. It was frozen, too.
1553322212222222222221.title: Tommy

1553322212222222222222.content: Those who created her did not give her a name. But she will learn about where she came from, and decide for herself where she fits in the world.
1553322212222222222222.title: Someone else

15533222122222222222221.content:
"Good morning, Subject 147," said the man in the white coat.

"Good morning," I reply.

Every morning of my life has begun this way. I am greeted, I respond in kind, and my training begins for the day. I'm not sure what I'm training for, but I hope I'll be good at it.

On this day, my training began with me on the treadmill. Whatever my results, I am always assured that I've done very well.

After running on the treadmill, I went to take a shower, to wash off the sweat before bacteria can grow and cause body odor. I know that body odor is disagreeable, since some people here do not seem to shower every day.

When I came out of the shower, I saw a slip of paper laying where the man in the white coat had been standing. I inferred that he had dropped it, but I had no way to contact him to return it.

Looking at the paper, I was surprised to find that it was about me. It clearly said Subject 147 right at the top, and that is what all the people in white coats called me. Since it was about me, I saw no reason why I should not read it.

What I read amazed me. Apparently, I had been born here, grown in an artificial womb. I had no memories of being anywhere else, but it was still a surprise to see that it was because I had never been anywhere else.
