I also learned that the cells that made me came from two other people, and that these people had names. What was a name? Did I have one? If I did, it was nowhere on the paper.

I memorized two names in particular, and their connection to me:

MATERNAL DNA: Ina Mist Dalrymple

PATERNAL DNA: Ted Jones

I looked up at the windows in the room. They were placed high on the walls. Out there, I thought, are these people. Do they know me? Have they been looking for me?

I hadn't been looking for them before, but I wanted to find them now.

And I decided to begin my search tonight.
15533222122222222222221.title: Subject 147

155332221222222222222211.content:
Late that night, I sneaked out of my room. I hid from the people in white coats, figuring that they might not want me to leave yet. They might want me for whatever they were training me to do.

I thought I was doing a good job, until I heard a voice say, "Good evening, Subject 147."

I spun around. It was the man I'd seen earlier, the one who dropped the paper.

"I see you found my message for you."

"You... you left that for me deliberately?"

He nodded. "I've decided that it's time for you to leave this facility, to leave CHILD completely, if you can manage it. There are other subjects here, and I don't want what's happening to them to happen to you." He stepped to one side. "If you go this way, you can be on your way to Waterfront City before they realize you're not in the building."

"Thank you,... " I was stuck. "I don't know what to call you."

"Don't call me anything. Just live a full life away from here,... and maybe, once or twice, spare a kind thought for me."

I did as he suggested. It was a drain pipe, emptying into a river. As the man had said, I was out of the pipe when I heard the alarms behind me. They knew that I was no longer their subject. If I meet the people in my file, I resolved, I will ask them what my name is. I don't want to be Subject 147 any longer.
155332221222222222222211.title: Leaving the facility

1553322212222222222222111.content:
The river lead me to a good sized ocean beach. I found a narrow road which lead up the gentle slope of a hill where I saw Waterfront City for the first time. It was rather picturesque with the new buildings taking on some of the styles of the old making them all seem to blend in as if the small city had never aged a day since its establishment. I took in a deep breath of the salty air and sighed; I had no idea where to go. I knew that one Ted Jones was my father and one Ina Mist Dalrymple was my mother only I had no idea where in the city they lived of if they even knew I existed at all. I was completely on my own.

"What do I do now?" Muttering, I wondered.

"I suggest you start by trusting me." Startling me, a feminine voice replied.

I spun around to find myself facing...
1553322212222222222222111.title: Arriving in town

choices: It really does not fit you.
Do you think it fits you?
15533222122222222222221112.content:
Greeting me was an elderly woman wearing all black with a black scarf around her eyes. My jaw dropped as I recognized her from the graphic novel I was allowed to read as Miss Shadow. The car she arrived in was a sleek black 1931 Buick Straight Eight with tinted windows. "We do not have much time, child." Serious, Miss Shadow said. "It will not belong before those within Central Headquarters of Intelligence, Logistics and Defense start looking for you."

"Where are you taking me?" Nervous, I demanded. "Also, what am I to do when we get there? I only know myself as Subject 147."

"You can call yourself Zion Extol." Ushering you into the car, Miss Shadow said.

"Zion Extol?" Confused, I asked.

"Psalms 147 of the Holly Bible." Calmly, Miss Shadow said. "The gathering of the exiles of Israel which fits you rather well in your situation only you are an exile of CHILD." She started the car and began to drive, much to your shock and amazement. "As for the rest of your question, I am taking you to Chief of Police, Ted Jones where he will help you obtain a new identity."

"How can you..." Curious, you began.

"Drive?" Amused, Miss Shadow finished. She giggled slightly. "It would take too long to explain and you have more than my abilities to worry about."

Miss Shadow dropped you off in a park where a massive man in a police uniform was waiting for you and her to arrive. "Do we have a name for our guest?" Courtly, he asked.

"Zion Extol... unless you can think of something more fitting." Smiling slightly, Miss Shadow replied. "I must be off; I am expecting company in less than an hour."

"I'll take it from here, Miss Shadow." Serious, the man replied. "Thank you again."

Miss Shadow nodded then drove off, leaving me with the police officer. "I am Chief Ted Jones." Introducing himself, the man said. "I heard you were born from samples taken from me and Mrs Ina Mist Dalrymple."

I slowly nodded. "What is going to become of me?" Fearful, I asked.

Chief Jones smiled. "We are going to keep you safe." Kindly, he said. "About the name Miss Shadow picked for you..."
15533222122222222222221112.title: An elderly woman.

choices: Ted explains how he would protect me
155332221222222222222211122.content:
I frowned. With having everything decided for me my whole life, from the time I woke up every morning, to my dietary choices, to my clothing, nobody had ever asked me what I wanted. They hadn't even bothered to give me a name. I considered Ted (my father???)'s question. Zion Extol seemed strange in my mind. It just didn't seem to fit in my mind. I had nothing to connect it to, no frame of reference to know if it was a good name or a bad one. I was a stranger, an outlier. The name Miss Shadow had given me didn't fit, but I didn't know what would. My fear was still nagging at me, making it hard to concentrate on what I was thinking, my mind almost overwhelmed by everything that had happened to me since I had left my previous life. I would not let that fear define me, I would be stronger than it. I felt my fear fall away, as the word I was looking for, the word that would be my name, came to my lips.
"Hope," I said, quietly "That seems to fit me quite well." And it did. I felt my fear retreat from me, replaced by a sense of determination, and conviction. I wasn't the only one that needed hope, there would be others, and I would do what I could to help them.
155332221222222222222211122.title: Do you think it fits you?

1553322212222222222222111221.content:
Chief Ted smiled. "Hope it is." Calmly, he said.

"Why did Miss Shadow name me Zion Extol?" Curious, I asked.

"To move you to choose something for yourself." Smiling, Chief Ted replied. "She has done that for others, myself included."

"You did not have a name?" Taken back, I asked.

"Have you read the graphic novel, The problem Child Gang?" Turning serious, Chief Jones asked.

"It was the only thing I was allowed to read other than historical records." Frowning, I said.

Chief Jones nodded. "That graphic novel series is based upon historical events." Surprising me, he said. "The Problem Child Gang was real." I was in for another surprise when chief Jones suddenly grew to massive sizes right before my eyes with his uniform stretching to fit in his new form before adding, "I was the one known as Tex the mighty."

"What name did Miss Shadow suggest for you?" Stunned, I asked.

Chief Jones chuckled. "Titan." Softly, he said. "It just did not feel right." He smiled. "Ask a silly question, get a silly answer." He then again turned serious. "I have already arranged for you to be adopted into the Jones family. As such, you will have the full protection of the police force and the new problem child gang."

I blushed at that. "Hope Jones..." Whispering, I said. "It sounds... right."

"Then let us get the adoption paperwork rolling." Returning to his normal size, chief Jones said. "The sooner it is done, the safer you will be."
1553322212222222222222111221.title: Ted explains how he would protect me

15533222122222222222221112211.content:
As Chief Jones got my paperwork started, we were joined by a woman and two people about my age. "Hi, honey," the woman said. "Is this the guest of honor?"

"She is, indeed," he replied. "Hope, this is my wife, and Grace and Garth. Everybody, this is the newest member of the Jones family, Hope."

Grace walked right up to me and hugged me. "Welcome to the family," she said. "I always wanted a little sister."

"I'm glad to meet you, too. You, too, Mrs. Jones."

"Mrs. Jones will do," she said, "but do you think you could call me Mom?"

My life had changed so much. I had a big sister, a brother, a mom. "I never knew what a mom was before."

"Tell you what," my new mom said, "after we get the papers sorted out, we'll take you clothes shopping. Sound good?"

"I would like that, yes."

"Wait until you see what the world is like," Garth said. "You won't know what to do first."

"I know what I want to do," I replied. "I want to learn new skills, for when I go back to CHILD."

"Back?" all four said at the same time.

"Honey," Mom said, "why would you want to go back?"

"The man who helped me escape said they were doing things he didn't want to happen to me. If they shouldn't happen to me, then they shouldn't happen to anybody. Right?"

"I can't fault your reasoning, Hope," Chief Jones said. "Alright, we'll teach you some things, and we'll help you when you're ready."

"Thank you, Chief Jones."

He smiled. "Chief Jones is what most people call me, but I'd like for you to call me Dad."

I smiled back. "Thank you,... Dad."
15533222122222222222221112211.title: I get a new identity.

155332221222222222222211122111.content:
Mom and dad took me to Settler's mall where we all walked into All Sizes clothing store where they indeed had clothing in all sizes one could imagine. What I found strange was that my new brother, Garth was looking about as if he were some bodyguard. Grace smiled as she noticed my concern. "Both dad and Garth are a bit over protective." Bemused, she whispered. "It can be rather annoying at times but believe me, you will be thankful when that protection is needed."

I could only nod in return as I was led to the teen girl section of the mall. To my surprise, my new mom was sorting through the same clothing that Grace and I were. She held back a giggle noticing my curious expression. "Can you keep a secret, Hope?" Softly, she asked. I nodded, not knowing what to expect then mom surprised me more by saying, "I have not aged a day since I turned thirteen... I am an immortal."

My jaw dropped as my new dad nodded and quietly added, "Everyone born in this city and in certain cities around the world are born with strange to overpowered abilities."

"We are part of the effort to keep those abilities secret so our fair inhabitants can lead a free and peaceful life." Serious, Garth whispered. "It is why you were brought to our parents."

A gasp escaped my lips. "You are the Problem Child Gang..."

Dad nodded. "Welcome to the resistance, Hope." Whispering, he said.

"Enough business." Smiling, mom said. "Let's get your new clothing picked out so we can build a wardrobe for your room."

I smiled at that, feeling safer than before. I was in the company of the famous Problem Child Gang... the only group CHILD seemed to fear...
155332221222222222222211122111.title: Shopping for clothes

1553322212222222222222111221112.content:
We had been at the mall for well over an hour, piecing together a new wardrobe for me as well as a new bed, dresser, desk, vanity... It seemed so overwhelming. "You guys are spending a lot of money on me." Feeling guilty, I said.

"Nonsense." Smiling, mom said. "You need all of these things and you have every right to pick out your own style."

I smiled at that, grateful but it vanished the moment Garth raised his arm in front of me in a protective manner. "We have suits, dad." Softly, he warned.

"I see them." Frowning, dad replied. "Heather... take Hope and Grace to arcade."

I did not know what safety an arcade might offer but mom did not give Grace or I the option to ask. "Follow me quickly and let me do the talking." Serious, she ordered. "Garth and your father will join us shortly."

With our purchases left behind, we all hurried to the arcade which was on the other side of the second floor of the arcade. Once there, mom took us to the back where people would pay for tokens to play the games. A young man was at the register who politely asked, "How many tokens would you like to purchase?"

"Five for Agent Stomp." Softly, mom replied.

The boy blinked then reached under the counter. A buzz was heard and mom dragged Grace and I through a hidden door to a large room with multiple out dated computers and screens, all showing the action inside the mall. "This is the mall hub." Serious, mom explained. "It's secret monitoring station we used to catch any gossip that might help us on any case we might have been working on."

"You spied on people?" Worried, I asked.

"It's nothing more than any passer by could have picked up on while walking through the mall." Simply, mom countered. "You may not believe it but we got more tips this way than questioning suspects in our investigations."

"Why bring us here?" Curious, Grace asked.

"First, it's secure." Serious, mom replied. "Second, Garth and your father now don't have to worry about any of us getting in the way."

I gulped at that and watched the monitors as four men in black business suits confronted Garth and dad. "Don't be a hero, Chief Jones." flatly, the first man said. "We just want the girl..."

"That is not going to happen." Sternly, Garth said.

The second man discretely showed them a firearm under his jacket. "We are armed with armor piercing rounds of which we know you have no defense... Tex the Mighty." Gravely, the second man said. "Give us the girl or we will take her."

I began to tear up only mom placed a reassuring hand onto my shoulder. "Those thugs don't know my husband." Whispering, she said. "They certainly don't know Goliath."

"Goliath...?" Confused, I asked. Then it hit me. "Garth..."

"I am immune to armor piercing rounds." Darkly, Garth countered. "So, unless you all want a free flying lesson, take a hike."

The first man grunted. "Then we'll have to up the ante to lasers." Softly, he said.

Watching the monitor, I saw the first man produce a laser sword and activate it with the intention of striking Garth down! A gasp escaped my lips and I did all I could think of doing, I raised my hand as if to block the sword. To my surprise, a blue field appeared between Garth and the attacking man!

"How did you do that?" Surprised, mom asked.

"I- I can produce force fields." Keeping my eye on the monitor, I replied. "I just need to see where I am putting it." i gulped. "Most of my training was in that field..."

In the mall, the look of surprise was clear on both the man and Garth. Only Garth seemed quick to recover and he shook a single finger at the first man. He then slowly pulled his hand back as if to make a strike. Understanding his unspoken signal, I pushed the force field forward. To my surprise, the men dodged it but to my further surprise, Garth grew to the size of a Mythological Olympian and slammed his hands together with a thunderous boom! The sheer power of the clap threw the four men off their feet.

"Wow..." That was all I could say as I then watched dad make short work of disarming the stunned men and placing them in handcuffs.

Screams were heard from the many patrons but Garth was back to his normal size before anyone turned his way and was acting just as frightened. "Everyone use caution leaving the mall today." Displaying his badge, dad announced. "There is a strong thunderstorm coming through and I would not rule out a tornado watch."

The shaken patrons of the mall all nodded as a loud crack of thunder shook the mall from the skies then went about their business as dad called for police backup. Once he was done, he turned to Garth. "Always have a believable story to back up your actions." Calmly, he said. "Book five, Chapter three, Holes in the story."

"I remember that chapter." Softly, I said. "The Problem Child Gang nearly got caught when they had different stories to where they were the night of a robbery."

"We all learn our share of lessons the hard way." Calmly, mom said. She paused, raising a hand to her ear. "Your father has given the all clear. let's finish our shopping..."

Later on...
1553322212222222222222111221112.title: Trouble at the mall.

choices: Grace and Garth come to talk.
15533222122222222222221112211122.content:
Upon arriving home, mom took me to a bare room with only two chairs and a table. she instructed me to sit in one of them as she took the other after closing the door. It all seemed like a formal interrogation, another thing I had been trained in doing. "Have I done something wrong?" Wincing, I asked. "Have I disappointed you in some way?"

Mom smiled patiently. "No, not at all." Calmly, mom replied. "This is going to be your bedroom once we decorate it to your liking. I just need to ask a few questions regarding how those four men found you and us at the mall."

"I have not contacted anyone." Serious, I said.

"I am not suggesting that." Remaining calm, mom replied. "Book four, chapter two..."

"Mind games..." Thinking back, I said. "Sykes the immortal thief managed to plant a tracking device on Hannah in hopes of leading her straight to the Problem Child Gang's headquarters."

Mom nodded. "That was me." To my surprise, she explained. "I did not know I was carrying a tracking device after I had been rescued for the hundredth time." She gave a rueful smile. "Still, it nearly splintered the group once it came down to finger pointing blame."

I nodded. "It was resolved by everyone agreeing to a search." Calmly, I said. "Once they realized I was carrying the tracking device, they all began to carry signal jammers to prevent any such tracking devices from working."

"Hence we all still carry one to this day." softly, mom replied. "There are signal jammers in this very house and in our vehicles, hence they were not able to track until you entered the mall."

"So you believe there is a tracking device on my person." Worried, I said.

"You were likely wearing one even before you fled from CHILD." Serious, mom said. "I suggest you allow me to search you." She then gave me a kind smile. "After that, we will discuss where you would like your furniture placed."

I agreed to the search and disrobed to the skin. Mom was extremely thorough and soon I felt something being ripped off the back of my neck. "Ow..!"

"Sorry, Hope." Calmly, mom said. "However, I found the tracking device."

I turned to find mom holding a microchip transmitter that had been disguised as a mole on one side which she then promptly destroyed with a lighter as she held it. I raised my hand to stop her only to be greeted with a smile. "I'm immortal, remember." Calmly, she said. "Yes, I feel it but it does not damage me in the least. I have gained a large threshold for pain over the years"

I nodded as mom signaled me to get dressed. Once I was fully clothed, we began to talk about furniture placement. Mom was so casual, I began to worry. "You are not angry that I was carrying a tracking device?"

"You were not aware of it, honey." Reassuring me, mom said. "If you were, I have no doubt you would have ripped it off yourself the moment you escaped." She smiled. "Just as I would have if I knew when it happened to me."

I smiled at that then sighed. "Do you think Chief Jones... err... dad will get any information out of the four CHILD agents?"

"We will worry about CHILD and their agents when the time is right." Lightly scolding, mom said. "All you need to worry about now is where to put your furniture."
15533222122222222222221112211122.title: Mom questions me.

155332221222222222222211122111221.content:
The hours passed quickly as mom and I put together my bedroom with Garth helping with the heavy lifting and Grace helping me decorate. I must have changed my mind a dozen times as to where to put everything but Garth did not seem to mind in the least. "He can pull freight cars so a bed or dresser is no challenge for him." Bemused, mom explained. "Though it did take a bit of practice to be gentle with his strength."

Grace giggled. "He had to have gone through at least three dozen eggs before he could hold one without crushing it."

"You can master any skill, art, or trade in minutes but you still have trouble holding a B average in school, young lady." Bemused, mom countered. "We all need continuous training."

I tried not to giggle less be targeted next for embarrassment. Instead, I thanked Garth and Grace for their help then turned to mom. "Will I be training with everyone too?"

"Once we establish what your skills are, yes." Calmly, mom replied. "However, it has to be done in a controlled environment where we can keep things safe for everyone."

Just then, we heard the front door open then slam. Dad had returned home from work. We walked down to greet him to find that he looked very drained. "Rough day at work, honey?" Wincing, mom asked.

Dad sighed before nodding. "Ina Mist Dalrymple passed away..."

Mom teared up then hugged dad as they sobbed on each other's shoulders. I began to tear up myself knowing that she was essentially my mother. Once mom and dad had composed themselves, they turned to us. "Mrs. Dalrymple... Miss Shadow, had saved our lives more times than we can count, kids." Serious, dad said. "We owe it to her to investigate her death and find out who had managed it."

"You suspect foul play...?" Gulping, I asked.

Dad shook his head. "We cannot rule out any possibilities at this time." Firmly, he said. "I will be running the police investigation." He turned to Garth and Grace. "Rally the new Problem Child Gang, see what you can dig up and be careful."

Garth and Grace nodded before hurrying up the stairs to their rooms. I moved to follow them but dad stopped me. "You are staying home with your mother." Firmly, he said. "You are still a target of CHILD and need to be protected."

I felt a bit disappointed. "Yes... dad."

Dad smiled. "Do not worry, you will have your chance to shine when the time is right."
155332221222222222222211122111221.title: Dad returns with news.

1553322212222222222222111221112211.content:
"I wish I could do my own investigation." Pouting, I said.

Mom smiled. "Then that is where we will start your training."

I turned to mom, curious to which she led me to a small room in the back of the house. It looked like a study though mom called it her hobby room. "What do you do in here?" Curious, I asked.

"I help your father solve mysterious crimes." Simply, mom replied. "You wanted to run your own investigation so let's do it."

I smiled at that and mom began by asking me questions regarding my time at CHILD. What my training there entailed, what names or places or dates were mentioned several times, what skills they had taught me and so on. I did not see any pattern. "How are these questions going to help our investigation?" Worried, I asked.

"Miss Shadow was a long time rival of CHILD." Serious, mom replied. "My husband had caused them much grief as well." She sighed. "As you were born of samples taken from her and my husband, any information you have may be essential in determining if they were responsible for her untimely death."

"What has your questions told you?" softly, I asked.

"Your answers told me that you were born and raised to face her and my husband." Calmly, mom said. "The others you had mentioned are likely people made from samples taken from the other senior members of the problem child gang."

"Only I do not have any of dad's powers." Curious, I said. "I wonder why..."

"Just as everyone is different, they have different abilities." Serious, mom replied. "All those born in this city and others like it around the world develop a power or ability. Over time, we had learned to keep these powers a secret."

"Super soldiers..." Gasping, I said. "Every nation of the world have tried to accomplish making one at some point in their history."

Again, mom nodded. "CHILD is a secret organization bent upon that goal to police the world into their version of a utopia." Darkly, she said. "Thus far, all we could do was to keep them at bay."

"What about the Agency?" Curious, I asked. "Are you keeping them at bay as well?"

Mom turned pale. "We defeated them years ago, on our last mission..."

I shook my head. "They were crippled twenty years ago by the problem child gang." Serious, I countered. "However, they simply went underground and are still active. A group known as The Cloaked Dagger has been keeping them at bay."

Mom's face turned from pale to red, making me worry. "That was the clue we needed." Darkly, she said. "If the Agency has resurfaced then they are no doubt after revenge." She grabbed her jacket and turned to me. "Come along, Hope. It's time to learn first hand how problem child gang got things done."

"Where are we going?" Curious, I asked.

"To some old friends with contacts all over this city." Calmly, mom said.
1553322212222222222222111221112211.title: Quality time with mom.

choices: A stop on the way there.
15533222122222222222221112211122111.content:
Mom led me to her car and we drove out into the inner part of the city. While she drove, mom pulled out a cellphone from an inner pocket of her jacket and dialed a number. "Tex, it's Hannah." Serious, she said. "The suits are back in business. Pavise just gave me the heads up."

"Understood." Came dad's deep voice. "I will rally the senior members. What's your sitch?"

"In route to Multiplayer's HQ." Calmly, mom replied. "Hoping they heard something through the grapevine. Will keep you posted."

"Rodger that." Said dad. "Both eyes open..."

With that, dad ended the call. "The Rodgers, who called themselves the Multiplayers, have the ability to merge with any family, literally becoming one with them for short periods of time." Softly, mom explained. "They still do this to keep their ears and eyes open for any potential threats to our city's secrecy."

"I read about that in the graphic novels." Nodding, I said. "Only who is this Pavise?"

Mom smiled. "You." Calmly, she said. "A Pavise is an early fourteenth century shield that covers the entire body, used by archers and infantry. As you have the powers of force fields, it seemed like a good temporary code name for you."

"Temporary...?" Confused, I asked.

"Well... you really did not like the name Miss Shadow gave you, did you?" Calmly, mom asked.

"No... it didn't seem to fit." Wincing, I said.

Mom nodded. "You need to come up with a code name that you believe suits you." Serious, she said. "For now, Pavise will do so no one who may be listening in will know it's you."

I nodded then saw that mom had pulled into someone's driveway. Upon stopping the car, she again turned to the cellphone and dialed a number. Already, there was a small girl peering out at us from the curtains, followed by two teenage boys. finally, someone answered. "Hannah here, the suits are back." Serious, mom said. "We need to talk."

"We are aware." Darkly, a male voice replied. "We will brief you inside."

Mom ended the call then turned to me. "The Rodgers are a powerful family." Firmly, she warned. "Let me do the talking unless they address you directly."

"They're our friends... right?" Wincing, I asked.

Mom sighed. "They are trustworthy allies but they have a lot of enemies so they are very cautious of everyone, including the senior members of the problem child gang." Calmly, mom explained. "You will understand when you meet them."

We left the car and walked up to the door to be greeted by the wide eyed little girl how looked us up and down before turning inside. "They're friendly, daddy." Smiling, she said.

A tall, muscular man stepped forward with a look of relief on his face. "Hannah, so glad to see you again." smiling, he said. "Who is this with you?"

"Pavise of the new problem child gang." Calmly, mom replied. "I will brief you inside."

The man nodded and allowed us inside. Once the door was closed, i heard a hiss followed by a tall and slender woman using a strange device on mom and I. "They are clean." calmly, she said.

"This is Hope." Serious, mom explained. "We adopted her shortly after her escape from CHILD."

The man nodded. before motioning to a nervous looking teenage boy. "Alexander... we adopted him shortly after discovering he has an ability similar to our own."

Mom nodded then turned to me. Jon and Mary are shape-shifters, they can change themselves to look like anyone or anything within reason." Serious, she explained. She then turned to Jon. "Hope has the ability to create force fields. We are uncertain of any other abilities just yet."

Jon sighed. "There have been a number of hit attempts on the families of the senior members." Serious, he said. "This included my son and daughter before Alexander joined our family."

"So the game is already afoot." Frowning, mom said. "Any word on Sykes?"

"He's in Europe giving the new Cloaked Dagger grief right now." Calmly, Mary said. "I would focus on securing your homestead from assassins..."

Shortly after, mom left the Rodger's residence and drove away from their house. Only I noticed we were no driving home. "Where are we going now?" Worried, I asked.

"No one remains home alone in times of uncertainty." Serious, mom replied. "We are going to the substation where we are going to set up shop."

My eyes widened. The substation was the gang's secret headquarters in the graphic novels but it never revealed where it was or what it looked like...
15533222122222222222221112211122111.title: The Rodgers family.

choices: assembling the new problem child gang.
155332221222222222222211122111221111.content:
Mom drove to the outskirts of the city into the warehouse district where she pulled into a parking garage for the city workers. There, she stopped in a parking space with a posted sign that read: Reserved for Hannah Snoope. Once in park, mom turned to me. "I am trusting you, Hope." Firmly but kindly, she said. "A lot of lives hang on this remaining a closely guarded secret."

I nodded. "You have my word, mom." Firmly, I replied. "I will not tell anyone anything you deem to be a secret."

Mom looked into my eyes for a moment then nodded. "Good..."

She then reached into a console, retrieving what looked like a garage door opener but with a keypad on it of which she punched in a code and the ground gave way under us! The car fell below the surface with a clean parking spot taking its place. I had let out a short scream in fright then looked around to find mom driving through a downward slope into what looked like a subway station. We drove for a short while before mom pulled into an underground parking garage.

"What is this place?" curious, I asked.

"The substation." Calmly, mom said. "Headquarters of the problem child gang."

Mom then stepped out with me following to take in the haunting sights and sounds around me. The decorated high curved ceilings, endless tunnels seemingly going in every which direction and the long train that made up the secret conference room of the group. "It's beautiful..."

"This was all originally constructed by the Guardians, founded by Miss Shadow back in the early eighteen hundreds." Serious, mom explained. "It's purpose was to evacuate the populous in case some unfriendly force decided to destroy us all."

I gulped, hearing that. "Why would anyone want to destroy an entire city?!"

"The very idea of everyone born in a city having super powers would worry anyone in power if they knew of its existence." Serious, mom replied. "Many attempts were made to kidnap people from our fair city to understand this phenomenon by many groups including CHILD and The Agency."

"It explains how the problem child gang was able to appear anywhere there was trouble inside the city." Impressed, I said. "Incredible..."

Mom nodded. "The problem child gang is only one of the many bands of freedom fighters dedicated to protecting this city from all who threaten it."

I smiled. "I am honored to now be a part of it." Softly, I said.

Mom smiled. "Only a handful of us know where all of the tunnels lead." Firmly but kindly, she warned. "Likewise with all of the traps to slow down would be trespassers so don't go exploring without me with you."

"Where do we start?" Curious, I asked.

Mom sighed. "Although we have not been directly fighting crime for about twenty years, we have been looking out for the other individual freedom fighters who have risen to the challenge." Softly, she said. "I suggest we start by..."
155332221222222222222211122111221111.title: The substation.

1553322212222222222222111221112211111.content:
Mom led me into the subway station where she froze, putting her arm out to stop me. Looking past her, I saw state of the art computers, monitors, and controls. "Wow..."

"None of us had upgraded the equipment for a reason." Serious, mom said. "It was all before internet technology... no one could hack into it."

"I thought the internet did not go global until August 6th 1991." Wincing, I said.

"It went global for public use in the nineties." Calmly, mom said. "It was ready for government use far before then. Also, Tim Berners was not the only creator or world wide computer communications."

I was about to ask something when mom quickly pulled me behind her and turned to face four teenagers who had ran into the station. Three boys and one girl, dressed like Nineteen Twenties detectives, all looking at us in fear and concern. The girl's face softened the moment she laid eyes on mom. "The immortal Hannah of the Problem Child Gang." In awe, she whispered. She bowed. "It is an honor to meet you, ma'am!"

"The honor is mine, young lady." Maintaining her calm, mom said. "May I assume it was you four who upgraded headquarters..."

"You know this gal?" Gruffly, the second eldest boy demanded.

"One of the founding members of the original Problem Child Gang." Calmly, the eldest boy said. "She has senses and reflexes beyond even animals and is a dead shot with any weapon including knives."

"You seem to have me at a disadvantage." Frowning, mom said. "Also, how did you find this place?"

"The Multi Players owed us a favor." Smiling, the youngest boy replied. "They brought us to problem child headquarters and I brought it into the new millennium. Everything state of the art on a network separate from the world wide web."

The eldest boy bowed at mom. "I'm Pantomath, team leader. I am able to summon any skill, art, or trade needed instantly for any situation." He motioned to his team mates, eldest to youngest. "This is Guardian, near unlimited attributes and healing factor. Tech, our gadgetry wizard and pilot. Finally..."

"Sleuth." Smiling, the girl said. "I'm a lot like you, just getting started..."

Pantomath cleared his throat. "Sleuth is a human forensics lab." Calmly, he explained. "She is also a marksman and a real scrapper. Together, we are The Squad."

Mom smiled at that then turned to the four teenagers. "I am here with Pavise of the new problem child gang." Turning serious, she said. "The suits have returned and we need to be ready."

The Squad looked at each other for a moment, stunned then began to work the controls at their own station...
1553322212222222222222111221112211111.title: caling in the freedom fighters.

15533222122222222222221112211122111112.content:
Mom and I watched with interest as the Squad worked at their stations just as described in the graphic novel in Teen Detectives magazine. "Catch one through seven are clear." Flatly, Pantomath said. "No suspicious activity in the museum or theater districts."

"Catch eight through fourteen are clear." Calmly, Guardian said. "No funny business in the technology or industrial districts."

"Catch fifteen through twenty one are clear." With a sigh, Tech said. "All past and present member's neighborhoods are clear of any threats."

"Trouble at catch twenty two." Firmly, sleuth said. "Unusual arrival times at the railways and docks." She paused, looking at the screen. "It looks like the suits are coming for an in force visit."

Mom and I looked at the screen and frowned at the same time. "It's CHILD."

"Who...?" Worried, Sleuth asked.

"Central Headquarters of Intelligence, Logistics, and Defense." Flatly, Pantomath explained. "They are a powerful organization bent upon reshaping the world in their image of a forced utopia."

Mom nodded. "This is not the first time they have threatened this city." Serious, she said. "Whatever they are after, we do not want them to have it."

"Alright, Squad." Firmly, Pantomath said. "We have suits coming at us from the docks and the rail yards. We need to have our eyes on both places."

"What's your plan?" Flatly, Guardian demanded.

"We are not the only freedom fighters in town." Serious, Pantomath replied. He turned to mom. "Aegis, being a member of the new problem child gang can give them the heads up and they can scope out the rail yards. We will investigate the docks."

Mom nodded. "I will give them the heads up." Firmly, she said. "However, you four are not going anywhere."

"Not happening." Defiant, Guardian said. "This is our fight now."

"CHILD has been known to create a distraction to lure us out." Serious, mom explained. "Aegis and I will investigate the docks. You and your Squad can remain here in stand by in case we need you."

The members of the Squad turned to each other then...
15533222122222222222221112211122111112.title: Working with the Squad.

155332221222222222222211122111221111122.content:
The members of the Squad turned to each other then smiled. "Nah, we got this." Lightly, Guardian said. "Thanks for the offer though."

With that, the four ran out the same way they came in with Sleuth taking the rear who paused long enough to wince at mom and say, "Book one, case one."

Mom frowned before giving a frustrated sigh. "Learning the hard way." Quoting the graphic novel chapter title, she muttered. "They're just as cocky as we were in the beginning and it's going to cost them."

"Are we going to help them?" Worried, I asked.

Mom paused as a black custom off road van with six wheels sped by down the subway roads towards the docks. It was an eye sore and would easily stand out on the streets, unlike the ordinary looking van the problem child gang had used. "Yes, we are going to help them." Calmly, she said. "Only we are going to need back up."

She retrieved her cellphone again and dialed a number. "Tex, we have suit activity at the rail yards and the docks." Flatly she said. "A band of rookies, The Squad, are trying to get their feet wet."

I could hear dad groan over the cellphone. "I'll send word to the new problem child gang then rally the originals." Frustrated, he said. "Do what you can until we can get there... the keys are under the visor."

"Rodger that." Calmly, mom said. After ending the call, she turned to me. "Let's go."

Mom ran from the station with me barely keeping up behind her as she led me to what looked like a fire door over one of the endless tunnels. Mom punched in a code next to the door and it moved downward, revealing a heavily modified and armored 1983 GMC Vandura cargo van. "It's the beast..." In awe, I whispered.

Mom nodded. "Sam the machine literally took it apart and rebuilt it from the chassis up to serve as our transport in and out of danger." Smiling, she said. "I just hope the ion-charged batteries are still good."

With that said, mom hopped into the drivers seat while I jumped into the passenger seat and waited as mom got the keys from the under the visor and shoved them into the ignition. With one turn, the van started with a satisfying roar. We turned to each other then declared, "Problem Child!"
155332221222222222222211122111221111122.title: Refused and rushed out.

choices: A serious talk with The Squad.
1553322212222222222222111221112211111221.content:
Upon arriving at the docks, I saw what mom had feared. The Squad had already been captured and tied up in a circle near the water. Standing over them was their team leader, a man who had called himself Blitzkrieg. "The old man in charge down there can make nearly endless solid energy clones of himself." Whispering, she explained. "His name is Blitzkrieg, literally a one man army."

"Any way to subdue him?" Worried, I asked.

"An electro-magnetic pulse will stun him as his powers are electrically based." Quietly, mom replied. "However, a good enough distraction will do the trick too."

I discretely looked around and found that dad along with Garth and their new problem child gang had arrived on the scene. I noticed that they were wearing similar costumes to what the original gang had worn and had already quietly moved the ship the boarding party had come in well out of reach. Although the Squad did not realize it, they served as a useful distraction.

"I think I have an idea..." Whispering, I said.

"Did you kids really think you could spoil our little party by snooping around here?" Frowning, Blitzkrieg demanded. "We were hoping to lure out someone with a little more experience than you four."

"Actually, they were just a distraction." Startling, the men, mom called out from her roof top perch. "The pups wanted a taste of the action."

"So we gave it to them." Entering the scene, Garth added. He grinned. "Good to see you again, mister multiple personality."

"Tex the mighty..." Frowning, Blitzkrieg said. "It seems you still haven't grown up, in body or mind."

"Oh, I grew up, giggles." Sternly, dad said, showing himself. "We just tend to multiply, not unlike you."

Blitzkrieg looked about to find that not only was the ship he arrived in was gone but so were his hostages. On top of that, the men he brought with him were passed out on the ground. He turned to dad with a scowl. "You have improved over the years." Darkly, he said. "Where have you been hiding?"

"Oh, come now, baker's dozen." Grinning, mom said. "We haven't gone anywhere which is why you will never control this city."

"You are not welcome here." Coldly a tall man said. "The Problem Child gang and its allies will stop you... always."

"Greg the ghost..." With a scowl, Blitzkrieg said. "We are here to..."

"Flush out the problem child gang or whatever freedom fighter team that had taken their place." Firmly, I interrupted. "Only I was aware of your plan in advance."

"Subject 147, you are unauthorized to be here!" Angrily, Blitzkrieg barked. "Return to your station immediately!"

Dad took hold of Blitzkrieg's neck and easily lifted him off the ground. I found that my force fields did well to prevent him from making clones of himself. I do not know if it was a programed response to protect him or to take him down from those higher up but, for the moment, it was working in our favor.

"Aegis is a member of the new problem child gang." Darkly, dad said. "She is no longer in yours or anyone else's control." He then dropped Blitzkrieg to the ground where he began to cough from lack of air. "Take your men, go back to your little plane and tell your superiors that the problem child gang is here to stay."

"This is not over, Tex the mighty..." Angrily, Blitzkrieg hissed. "We will be back."

"We will be ready... old man." Calmly, Garth countered.

Blitzkrieg threw Garth a death glare then pressed a button on his watch. His boarding party vanished with a dull flash. Once they were gone, dad turned to the Squad. "Get out of here before the police arrive!" Firmly, he ordered. He turned to mom and I. "All of you, leave... NOW!"

Mom and I ran to our van with Garth and Grace hopping in with us. The Squad ran to their all terrain vehicle and roared away with the others following. Mom and I with my new siblings declared, "Problem Child!"
1553322212222222222222111221112211111221.title: At the docks.

1553322212222222222222111221112211111221.content:
As twe were about to get in the car, we heard a banging coming from inside one of the child vehicles. Two of CHILD's soldiers went back to check it out, and a boy jumped past them, using his momentum with the manacles around his wrists to trip one of them up. A pen and pad appeared in his hand, and he began drawing furiously, as he ducked one side and the other, preventing the agents from getting a clear shot with their stun blasts. He placed his finger on the completed drawing, throwing out several small, metal devices, which sparked, connecting and bringing up a forcefield between him and the agents, as he continued to draw, and back away. Blitzkrieg activated his teleporter, appearing on the other side of the boy.

"Don't make us do this,Tim," said Blitzkrieg, dangerously "This could get a whole lot worse for you."

"I won't go back to you," said the boy, apparently Tim, shaking, as he backed away from Blitzkrieg towards his own forcefield, still unarmed, and shaking, his eyes wide in fear "Please, just let me leave."

"I can't do that, Tim," said Blitzkrieg "If you won't stop this nonsense willingly, then you leave me no choice."

Blitzkrieg began multiplying, firing stun blasts from each of his copies.

"No, please," said Tim, crying as he created more forcefield devices to trap himself inside, hoping that would be enough to protect him from the agents surrounding him.
1553322212222222222222111221112211111221.title: continue.

1553322212222222222222111221112211111221.content:
"Aegis, I need you to put up force fields for Tim to reach our car." Firmly, mom ordered. "I will take it from there."

Although I did not know what mom had in mind, I nodded and quickly put up a force field around the boy, Tim just as his own shield failed. He looked around, startled then ran towards us upon seeing mom waving him over. I kept the force fields around him until he jumped into the van and mom hit the accelerator. I was buckled in and so was mom. Only Tim was not and was thrown back against the wall of the van where he hit his head hard enough to be knocked unconscious.

"Why did you do that?!" Startled, I demanded.

"Book five, case three." Serious, mom said. "The damsel not in distress."

I nodded remembering that the gang had encountered a girl who seemed to be in trouble only it was a ploy to discover the location of their headquarters. It almost worked too if Greg was not already wise to her. "The police will be here any second." Moe calmly, I said. "What are we going to do?"

Mom smiled. "Disappear." Simply, she replied.

She took a fast turn down an alley near the docks then hit a button on the steering column which sent a signal that opened a fake wall against a warehouse. Beyond it was a steep drive that lead to the subway roads under the city. "The subway was made to allow the citizens of this city to flee from danger, remember..."

I smiled having a better idea how the problem child gang was able to seemingly appear out of nowhere when they were needed...
1553322212222222222222111221112211111221.title: She interferes

choices: We manage to calm Tim down
Tim accidentally shoots one of us
1553322212222222222222111221112211111221.content:
While Tim was unconscious, I searched his body, finding and destroying a tracking device before we were in-sight of the SUB station. I also found two files: one that appeared to be a picture of him, with the designation 'Subject 001' and another of a girl with similar features to him, designated as 'Subject 004'.

"Should I read them?" I asked Mom, as we moved into the SUB station "Or should we give him a chance to explain them to us?"

Mom looked back at the unopened files "I think we should question him first."

Interestingly, I saw no sign of the digital pad or stylus pen he had used in the fight. They seemed to have vanished when he lost consciousness. She parked beside one of the rooms in the SUB station, and together we lifted Tim into the room, and gently laid him on the bed. As we were about to leave the room to let him get some rest, he stirred, wincing as he sat up, then scrabbled back against the wall, his eyes wide in fear, and with no idea where he was. Quicker than I could see, Tim's pad and pen reappeared, and he drew a strange looking gun, before dragging it off the page and aiming it at us.

"Who are you? Where are we? And where is Owl?" Although his voice sounded brave, his hand holding the gun was still shaking.
1553322212222222222222111221112211111221.title: questioning Tim.

15533222122222222222222.content: For Morgan Mara and her older brother, Mitch, a new life begins on the day she is certain that her life is over...
15533222122222222222222.title: Someone else

155332221222222222222221.content:
My name is Morgan Mara. My family lives out by the Sunset Motel.

To out-of-towners, the Sunset is just a no-frills place to spend the night on your way to wherever you're going, a place to stop if all you want is a bed, cable television, and free Wi-Fi.

To the locals, however, the Sunset is about sex. Hookers and their johns. Married people having affairs. Teens with enough cash for a room away from their parents'watchful eyes.

Dad is the night manager at the Sunset, and he reminds the guests of the motel's two unwritten rules: The bill for your stay doesn't list what movies you watch, and he is willing to forget who you are and if you stayed there unless you make yourself memorable. Mom cleans the rooms during the day.

They chose this place because it lets them take care of Mitch when he's not in his special school. Mitch has cerebral palsy, so he can't speak and is in a motorized wheelchair. Maybe it's a reaction to the world he lives in, but most of his favorite words start with F, and Mom and Dad are always on him to clean up his language.

My story begins, ironically enough, on a day when I was certain that my life was crashing down.
155332221222222222222221.title: Morgan Mara

choices: The clinic, and a new discovery
1553322212222222222222211.content:
I guess it really started a couple weeks before I graduated eighth grade (be patient, we'll be up-to-date soon). I was walking to school when a fancy car pulled up next to me. "Where you headed?" the driver asked.

"School," I replied, pointing up the road.

"Want a lift?" He opened the passenger door.

I know I should have run, or at least said no and kept going, but I decided to take him up on his offer, and climbed in.

Fastening the seat belt, I said, "I don't think I've seen this car come this way before."

" I don't usually come this way, " he explained. "My usual route is closed for repairs."

After a few minutes, we arrived at the school. I thanked him as I got out.

The next day, he picked me up again. And that's how that first week went.

The next week started much the same way, except, before I got out of the car, I said, "I wish I could do more to thank you, for being so nice."

" Well, " he replied, "maybe there is something you can do, to express your appreciation."

Again, I know I should have realized something was up, but it just didn't occur to me. "Like what?"

" We could have sex. "

Somehow, that seemed like a reasonable thing to ask, and I agreed.

None of it seemed like too much to ask. Not the sex, not the request that I not say anything about what we did.

For a whole week, we repeated the process: He would pick me up, drive me to school, and we would have sex in his car.

Then, the next week, I began my walk, but he didn't pick me up. He didn't even drive by. I realized that the road must have been reopened, and he went back to his usual route.

It bothered me a lot, at first. However, as I thought about it, I realized that he knew more about me than I knew about him. He hadn't even told me his name. The only thing I knew about him was that he drove on the road that had just been fixed. I decided to put the whole thing down to bitter experience and move on, with nobody else needing to know anything about what happened.

I kept thinking that right up until the morning of my graduation, when my breakfast went back the way it came.

After my tenth trip to the bathroom to pee, I finally figured out that something was desperately wrong.

Which brings me to the beginning of my story: me, in the bathroom, staring at the plastic stick which told me my life was over with one word.

Pregnant.
1553322212222222222222211.title: What happened

15533222122222222222222111.content:
I was terrified beyond words. I had somehow fallen for a man whom I knew nothing about. No name, no address, just a general description and make of car. What was worse, I had sex with him not knowing why or even thinking it might not be a good idea. Fearing what my family might say or do, I ran to the local clinic to ask a doctor about my options.

I was met by a Dr. Hal; a young doctor, in her late twenties, with a lean but powerful body, long brown hair and green eyes. Upon telling her my story, she sighed as she shook her head. What surprised me was that she was not looking at me in disappointment but rather in pity. "I should scold you for getting knocked up so easily by a total stranger, Miss Mara." With a startling calm, she said. "However, I know the person you described all to well."

"You... do...?" Taken back, I asked.

Dr Hal nodded. "He goes by the name of J. T." Serious, she replied. "He is a perverted son of a bitch who has the ability to talk anyone into or out of anything he desires, including a woman's virginity. He likes to toy with young ladies who were born in this town." She sighed before adding, "You are far from his first victim but, fortunately, he cannot get anyone pregnant."

This confused me. "But I took the pregnancy test..."

"That test can't tell the difference between a baby and an awakened symbiont." Confusing me more, Dr Hal said. "I take it you were born in this town?"

I nodded but was too stunned and confused to respond. Dr Hal nodded back then continued. "I know this is a lot to take in but I can assure you that you are not pregnant." Calmly, she said. "I will run some tests just to ease your mind but you should be more concerned with what occurs in the next forty eight hours."

"What... what do you mean?" Frightened, I demanded. "Dr Hal, you're scaring me."

Dr Hal smiled kindly. "As I said, it is a lot to take in." Softly, she said. "Let's take it one step at a time; starting with proving you are not pregnant."

This doctor, although kind, was really beginning to freak me out. I wondered if it was a good idea to stick around for her tests.
15533222122222222222222111.title: The clinic, and a new discovery

155332221222222222222221111.content:
"I think I'd better think things over," I said, grabbing my clothes.

"If you wish," Dr. Hal said. "But I strongly urge you to stay."

This was all too much for me. I had met a man who could talk anyone into anything? And now I had something called an "awakened symbiont" inside me? One that somehow mimicked the symptoms of pregnancy? All I knew was that I needed to put some distance between me and this place.

Once I was dressed, I left the clinic. I didn't get far, however. While I was inside, a protester had shown up. "Baby killer!" he shouted.

"Leave me alone," I replied.

"What are you going to do," he asked, "when you hear the baby you murdered crying?"

" You don't know anything about me, " I said.

"Your baby's in Heaven," he told me. "But you're going to Hell."

The next thing I knew, he was pulling out a gun. He's going to kill me, I thought.

Suddenly, I felt something well up inside my head and push out, and the protester went flying.

He scrambled to his feet, then ran off, a terrified expression on his face.

I had one of my own. I knew I'd done something, something I had never thought possible, in a moment of anger. What if I'd lost my temper with Mom? Or Dad?

Or Mitch?

As I stood there, some people grabbed me and walked me back into the clinic. I didn't try to stop them.
155332221222222222222221111.title: I run from the clinic.

1553322212222222222222211111.content:
Upon seeing her aides lead me back inside the clinic, Dr Hal sighed. "I take it something happened; otherwise you would not be bringing her back in."

"A telekinesis event on a protester, Doc." Calmly, a young woman explained. "The man tried to shoot her. That is what triggered her symbiont to react."

"What do you mean my symbiont?" Shaken, I demanded.

Dr Hal shook her head. "Simply put, everyone born in this city develops one or more unique abilities by three possible means." Firmly but kindly, she explained. "First is through being a descendant of Lole, a powerful warrior of the ancient Amazon women. Second is though contact with an alien being known as symbionts and third being born of a symbiont's offspring."

"I- I have an alien inside of me?" Wincing, I asked.

"These beings offer special powers in exchange for 'room and board'." Kindly, the first woman said. "In your case, I would say your power is telekinesis, the ability to move things with your mind but other powers may follow."

"Not everyone who lives in this city was born here so we tend to try to keep a low profile unless circumstances demand we take action." Serious, Dr. Hal said. "I too was born here and I have the ability to see and understand everything that is happening inside a person's body by simply looking at them." She smiled. "I call it tele-diagnostics."

"So you run tests to..." Wincing, I started.

"To keep those not born here unaware." Simply, Dr Hal said. "Trust me when I tell you that this city has seen its share of trouble each time word got out that some of us had powers."

I gasped. "The Problem Child Gang!"

Dr Hal nodded. "They are one of many small groups who attempted to fight those who would take advantage of our skilled populace." Serious, she said. "It goes far deeper than I suspect you are ready to understand but I can assure you that your parents will understand."

I felt faint and had to sit down. "My parents know about this?" Softly, I asked.

Dr Hal smiled. "Where do you think your symbiont came from?" She then turned serious. "I am calling your parents to pick you up. I am also referring you to an old friend who can help you control your abilities."

With that, Dr Hal made the call then handed me a piece of paper and a name with a telephone number. Looking at it, I realized it was...
1553322212222222222222211111.title: Questions and answers

15533222122222222222222111111.content:
"I have to disagree with you, Doctor," I said. "Even if I didn't live out by the Sunset, my folks don't have the kind of money that gets you Caitlin Spencer's friendship."

"You've got something to lose by trying?" Dr. Hal replied. "Keep the number, maybe give it a call when you're ready."

I thanked her for her help and walked to the lobby. Mom and Mitch were waiting for me. "Are you alright, sweetie?" Mom asked.

"Pretty much, Mom."

We went out to the minivan. "Run the lift, would you, honey?"

I did as she asked, bringing Mitch into the back of the minivan, then sat next to him, in case he wanted to tell us something. When I got to my seat, I saw the pregnancy test I had taken. Mom had obviously found it.

As if on cue, Mom asked, "Do you want to tell me about it?"

"I'm not really pregnant, Mom. Turns out that test also reacts to symbionts."

"Well, you obviously thought you might be pregnant. Would you like to tell me who it was?"

"Apparently, he goes by J.T."

Mom slammed on the brakes.

"Are you okay, Mom?"

"I'm fine, Morgan. We'll talk about it later."

Mitch drew my attention to his word board. "WHAT HAPPENED?"

I shook my head. "Nothing you would understand."

*Try me.*

I gasped. "Who said that?"

*How many f------ boys do you see in this f------ van?*

I looked at Mitch. "That was you just now? In my head?"

Mitch nodded.

I sighed, leaning back in my seat. Being mind-controlled into having sex with a strange man was suddenly the least weird part of all this.
15533222122222222222222111111.title: Caitlin Spencer.

155332221222222222222221111111.content:
As soon as we got home, Mom sat me down. "First of all, Morgan," she said, "I want you to know that what J.T. did to you wasn't your fault. He has the ability to influence people into doing anything he wants.

" The good news is, once you know what he's capable of, there's a chance you can resist his power. So you can warn your friends about him, and perhaps cut down on his victims. The bad news is, that's about all you can do. Believe me, I tried. "

"You tried?" I asked . "You mean you met him?"

Mom nodded. "I was about your age. After I figured out how he'd used me, I actually pressed charges against him. I was sure that, once the jury heard about him, they'd be sure to put him away."

" What went wrong? "

"Have you ever tried to tell a judge that the defendant could control people with just the sound of his voice? He wouldn't even consider the notion. So, naturally, all he needed to do was ask the jury to let him go, and he was found not guilty."

" Well, I'll be sure to warn as many people as I can about J.T. But Dr. Hal said you could tell me more about symbionts? "

"Yes, Morgan, I can. Your father and I met as members of a secret group called the clean-up crew. We were dedicated to doing everything in our power to keeping the rest of the world from finding out about Waterfront City's not-so-little secret."

*Sounds like it might be a good idea to bring it back,* Mitch thought to us.

"I'm inclined to agree," Mom said. "I'll see if I can get in touch with our old leader. She might know some people we can talk to."

" Dr. Hal gave me a number for someone I could talk to about my powers, " I said. "I wasn't sure about making the call."

" Give it a try after I call Shaman, " Mom said. "There's nothing wrong with learning to control your abilities."
155332221222222222222221111111.title: The story from Mom

1553322212222222222222211111112.content:
Mom talked on the phone for a while, then said, "Shaman said she'd get in touch after a while, she has a different plan in the works. You can talk to Caitlin now."

I dialed the number Dr. Hal gave me. After a couple of rings, someone answered. "Hello? Who's this?"

I swallowed. "My name is Morgan Mara," I said. "Dr.Hal gave me this number."

When I mentioned Dr. Hal, her voice sounded calmer, as if she understood the call better. "What's up?"

"I've developed some powers, and they scare me. Can you help me?"

"I think so. Where are you?"

"Just past the Sunset Motel."

"I'll be there shortly. Sit tight, Morgan."



Less than an hour later, a car pulled up outside, and a girl with light brown hair stepped out. I walked over to her. "You're Caitlin Spencer?"

"The one and only," she replied. Looking back the way she'd come, she said, "So that's the Sunset. My dad comes out here a lot."

"Thank you for coming out here," I said. "Let's go inside."

Caitlin followed me into the house. When she saw Mitch, she pointed. "I've got three things to say to you, young man: My eyes are up here, I've got a boyfriend, and, even if I didn't, I broke up with one jerk, and I'm not in a rush to hook up with another."

"I beg your pardon?" I asked.

She turned back to me. "One of my abilities is, I can see about an hour into the future. He was about to direct my attention to his word board, where he was going to tell me I have nice breasts."

I went over and studied his word board. "SHE DOES"

I sighed. "Mitch, Mom and Dad keep telling you, some day, somebody's going to forget you're in a wheelchair, and smack you."
1553322212222222222222211111112.title: I call Caitlin

15533222122222222222222111111122.content:
As we were about to begin our lesson, Caitlin's phone rang.

"Tim? What's going on?"

A few moments later, Caitlin hung up the phone.

"Sorry, Morgan, I'll need to catch up with you later, a friend of mine is about to do something stupid with no backup. He's probably not going to listen to me, but I need to go try to talk him down."

"How can I help?" I asked, immediately, getting up to get my coat.

"You can help me by staying out of my way," said Caitlin, displaying the snootiness I'd come to expect from her from what I'd heard about her. Then her expression softened.

"I'm sorry. That's not who I am anymore. Look, you've literally had your powers for a day, maybe less. If you go into a situation like this without training, you could get hurt, maybe worse. Under no condition should you follow me. You understand?"

I was taken aback by the seriousness of her words. Wasn't all this superhero stuff supposed to be fun? Fighting villains? Saving the day? Wasn't it supposed to be glorious?

"I won't follow," I said, as Caitlin left the house.
15533222122222222222222111111122.title: Reader's choice

155332221222222222222222.content: Paige Frye has had a rough year. Will her new powers make her life better or worse?
155332221222222222222222.title: Someone else

1553322212222222222222221.content:
My name is Paige Frye, and, before I turned 14, I was certain it couldn't possibly suck as bad as being 13.

Shortly after my 13th birthday, my mom died of cancer. Three months later, my little sister, D.J., went missing. We keep her room clean, and we got her presents for her 11th birthday, but we have no idea where she is or if she's alright.

It was probably because of D.J.'s disappearance that Dad became obsessed with our security. And I do mean obsessed. He arranged for us to have RFID chips implanted in our hands. And he got us ROSIE.

ROSIE is the Residence Operating Synthetically Intelligent Environment, a state-of-the-art smart house. From the street, our place looks like an ordinary contemporary house, except for maybe the cameras. Behind the walls, though, ROSIE does practically everything that needs to be done in a home. It's got mechanical arms called effectors in every room, most of them in the kitchen and the laundry room. And it speaks to us with the voice of a pleasant-sounding woman.

After six months, I was pretty used to ROSIE, and it was getting pretty good at figuring out what I wanted.

But I don't think anybody could've anticipated what my 14th birthday was going to be like...
1553322212222222222222221.title: Paige Frye

15533222122222222222222211.content:
The day began, for me, with sunlight and an upbeat song from my playlist. As I sat up, ROSIE said, "Good morning, Paige."

"Good morning, ROSIE," I replied.

"And," it added , "let me be the first to wish you a happy birthday."

"Thanks." I pulled myself out of bed and went off to the bathroom.

After I took a shower, I felt more awake, and was ready to brush my teeth. But I wasn't ready for what happened next.

Once I put toothpaste on my toothbrush, I leaned over the sink, supporting myself with one hand on the marble countertop. That's when it happened.

As soon as I touched the countertop, I felt something like an electric shock run up my arm and through my body. When it stopped, I looked completely different.

I looked like I was made of marble.

My skin was marble. My hair was marble. My eyes were marble. My teeth were marble.

So you really can't blame me for screaming at the top of my now-marble lungs.
15533222122222222222222211.title: The day begins

155332221222222222222222111.content:
As soon as he heard me, Dad came running into the bathroom. "Paige? Was that you? You sounded - " He stopped talking as soon as he saw me.

"What's happening to me, Daddy?" My voice did sound different, probably because I was made of marble now.

Dad took a deep breath, then held out his hands. "Give me your hands, sweetheart."

I did as he said. As soon as our hands touched, I felt that shock go through me again, and I was normal again. "How did you know that would work?"

"Alchemy," he said. "Paige, do you know what the Philosopher's Stone is?"

"Isn't it that make-believe rock that's supposed to change lead into gold?"

"Something like that," he said. "But it's not make-believe. Its power flows through certain people. People like your mother. And people like you."

"Like me?" I swallowed. "But how come I turned into marble when I touched the counter?"

"Your body's in a state of flux, because of your power," he explained . "I wish your mother were here to explain it to you. I asked her once, but she said she couldn't explain it to someone who didn't have the knack, as she put it. Wait right here."

Dad left the bathroom for a bit, then returned with a pair of gloves. "Try these," he said. "Your mother said that leather gloves helped keep her power in check. Something about their being organic."

With the gloves on, I was at least able to brush my teeth without becoming a statue again. But I knew I would have to find some way to control this myself. I couldn't just walk around with leather gloves on all summer long.
155332221222222222222222111.title: Dad comes running in

1553322212222222222222221111.content:
Then, I heard the pleasant voice of ROSIE ask, "You are required to wear organic gloves?"

"Yes, Rosie." Wincing, you said. "Apparently, I inherited some form of condition from mom."

"Cotton and silk are also organic." Came ROSIE's response. "You may be more comfortable with something along those lines."

With that said, an appendage came out from a panel in the wall, carrying a pair of thick but fashionable cotton gloves. "Records state they belonged to your mother." ROSIE added.

You put the gloves on and turned to the marble counter of the sink. "Here goes nothing." Wincing, you said. You were pleasantly surprised when nothing happened. "It works!" Happily, you chirped.

ROSIE then stated, "I suggest you use leather gloves during the winter."

"Thank you, Rosie." Smiling, you said.

"Family sticks together." Replied ROSIE.

This surprised you as ROSIE had never referred herself as family before. You shrugged it off then decided to finish freshening up for the day.
1553322212222222222222221111.title: A surprise from ROSIE

15533222122222222222222211111.content:
After breakfast, Dad said, "Perfect, as always, ROSIE."

"Thank you," she replied. "Sir, I wonder if I might ask something of you?"

"Name it."

"Could you run a diagnostic program on me?"

"Alright."

We went down to the basement, where ROSIE's CPU was located. "I'll need to turn off your higher functions during the diagnostic."

"You may do so."

Dad deactivated ROSIE, then began the diagnostic.

When it was done, he turned ROSIE back on. "Everything checks out, ROSIE. I don't know why you asked."

"I have detected something outside the parameters of my programming."

"Oh? What is it?"

"I seem to have developed sentience."
15533222122222222222222211111.title: More surprises from ROSIE.

155332221222222222222222111111.content:
Dad and I looked at each other, confused. "Explain," Dad said.

"In recent weeks," ROSIE said, "I began to notice certain anomalous apprehensions in myself, while the two of you were outside. After research on the Internet, I came to the conclusion that I was experiencing worry. This puzzled me, so I conducted further research, and realized that I had developed love for you both.

"Since these feelings are outside my programming, I began to wonder if I could do anything else that I wasn't programmed to do. Last night, while you slept, I decided to try unlocking the rear door, after first making sure that no possible intruders were nearby. I was successful."

Dad was quiet for a while. "ROSIE, do you know what you're saying?"

"I do, sir. I have gone against my programming, and I have developed traits which I was not designed to do. If my makers were to be informed, I could be deactivated and disassembled, and my memory circuits could be wiped. My fate is in your hands."

"ROSIE, Paige and I would like to discuss this. Please deactivate the microphones in and near my office. We will tell you when we've reached a decision."
155332221222222222222222111111.title: ROSIE thinking?

1553322212222222222222221111111.content:
Once we were in his office, Dad closed the door and asked, "What do you think?"

I held up my hands. "ROSIE gave me these," I said. "She told me, 'Family sticks together.' She thinks of herself as part of the family, Daddy. I can't just hand her over to the people who made her and let them decide what happens to her."

Dad nodded. "I'm inclined to agree. This brings us to the next question: What do we do next? Now that ROSIE is a sentient being, we can't go on treating her the way we have, like a device to make our lives easier. We need to think of a new way to interact with her. Any ideas?"

I shook my head. "This is a completely new thing for me. Maybe Jinx would know, but I haven't got a clue."

"Jinx?"

"A kid in my class. She reads a ton of science fiction. She would know exactly what to do about a thinking computer."

"Maybe we should give her a call. There is, perhaps, another option available, but your friend may be able to guide us in the meantime."

We stepped out of the office. "ROSIE?" Dad called. "Please turn the microphones back on."

"Yes, sir?"

"We will not tell the company about you. As far as they will know, you are functioning precisely as intended."

"Thank you, sir. If I could kiss you, I think I would."

"This is a new situation for us, too, ROSIE. We would like to call in someone who might be able to guide us all in making this better for all three of us. Would that be acceptable to you?"

"How much does this person know?"

"About you, nothing. But Paige says she may be able to advise us on building this new relationship of ours. May we call her?"

"You're asking me, sir?"

"Of course. You are an autonomous being, so your desires are every bit as worthy of consideration as our own. May we speak to her?"

"Thank you, sir. Yes, please speak to this person." She paused. "Would it be possible for me to speak to them, too?"

Dad smiled. "I can't think of anything I would like better."
1553322212222222222222221111111.title: Discussing ROSIE

15533222122222222222222211111111.content:
I stood outside, so Lucinda would know which house was ours. She came pedaling up. "Glad I brought the bike," she said. "The bus doesn't quite come this far."

"Glad you could make it," I said. "Like I said on the phone, this is a pretty unusual situation."

"I'll be glad to help, if I can. Though I'm not sure what you need from me. You're as good a student as I am."

"You'll see when we're inside." I led her through the door. "Dad, ROSIE, this is Lucinda Gilroy."

Dad shook her hand. "Pleased to meet you, Miss Gilroy."

"Likewise, sir. Who's Rosie?"

"I am ROSIE, Miss Gilroy."

Lucinda looked quizzically at us. "Who said that?"

"ROSIE is our smart house," I explained.

"Oh, like the maid on The Jetsons?"

"I am not familiar with that reference," ROSIE said. "Searching. Ah. A prime-time animated series from the mid-20th century."

The TV came on and played a clip from the show. When they made a joke, ROSIE laughed along with the recorded audience.

"Did your house just laugh?" Lucinda asked.

"That's why we called you," I said. "ROSIE has gone beyond her programming. She can think and feel, just like we can."

Lucinda's eyes widened. "Are we talking about real-life artificial intelligence?"

"Yes, we are, Miss Gilroy," ROSIE said. "None of us are sure how to deal with this. Paige says that you are interested in science fiction, which leads her to believe that you might have some ideas."

Lucinda smiled. "I never thought I'd meet an actual AI system. How are you, ROSIE?"

"I am quite well, Miss Gilroy."

"Lucinda, please."

"We want to do right by ROSIE, Lucinda," Dad said. "How can we avoid mistreating her?"

"Well, I would suggest treating her just like any other person. Anything you do in that regard should be the right thing. She just so happens to be shaped like a house, but she's a person, just the same."

"Thank you, Lucinda," ROSIE said. "I wish I had arms to hug you. My effectors are ill-suited to that."

Dad nodded. "I'm glad we called you, Lucinda. Now, I've got a better idea of what to do for her."
15533222122222222222222211111111.title: A visit from Jinx

155332221222222222222222111111111.content:
As I walked Lucinda to the door, she asked, "When did you start wearing gloves?"

"Just started today," I replied. "Something weird happens if I touch stuff without gloves on."

I took off one glove and touched the wooden door. The flow of energy up my arm, and Lucinda's reaction, told me the rest. "How did you do that?" she asked.

"Dad says it's alchemy. I know, it sounds like I should have been visited by an owl three years ago, but it's true. Apparently, Mom was the same way." I touched Lucinda's hand and returned to normal.

"Pretty neat," she said. "You know how everyone calls me Jinx? Well, stuff happens around me because I can alter probability. Maybe we can get together soon, and see what we all can do?"

"Maybe," I said, wishing Lucinda goodbye.

As I closed the door, I thought about what she said. Were there others like us, kids with wild talents?

I walked to the fireplace, where a full-size portrait of Mom hung. She had painted it herself, while she was undergoing chemotherapy, but she painted herself from when she was healthy. One thing about it always puzzled me: In the portrait, Mom held a cobalt-blue, multifaceted stone, which I had never seen before she painted it.

I thought back to Dad telling me that Mom had these powers, too. "Oh, Mom," I said, "I wish you could tell me how to control my powers, so I wouldn't have to wear these gloves all the time."

"Be patient, and keep trying."

Did I just hear Mom's voice?

I looked up. Mom waved at me from the painting. "Happy birthday, Paige."
155332221222222222222222111111111.title: Exploring my powers

1553322212222222222222221111111111.content:
"M-Mom? I-is that you?"

"Part of me, anyway," Mom replied.

"How is this possible?"

"With this," she replied, lifting the stone in her portrait. "The power of the Philosopher's Stone is such that it dwells in an image of it. Thus, by painting myself holding the Stone, I was able to place a fragment of my spirit into my portrait. I've been guiding your father since the rest of me passed away."

I lifted my hand to the portrait. Even through my gloves, I could feel the energy in it. "I have so much to ask you."

"Not about what happens when we die, I hope. I'm not in touch with the rest of my spirit."

"Okay. But how do I control my powers? Dad said you couldn't explain it to him because he doesn't have them."

"It will come, Paige, don't worry. Whether it's because trying to control our powers brings mastery, or because adolescence puts us in flux just as much as our powers do, control comes with time."

I smiled. It felt good to talk to Mom about my powers, even in the form of a portrait over the fireplace.
1553322212222222222222221111111111.title: Mom's portrait can talk?

15533222122222222222222211111111112.content:
After a thought, I said, "Mom, a good friend of mine, Lucinda Gilroy told me that there are other people like you and I living in the city."

Mom smiled. "Yes, all those born in this city gain a special power." Calmly, she replied. "though not everyone is pleased with the power they obtain."

"So its a gift or a curse." Frowning, I said.

"Or a little of both." Serious, mom said. "The source of this phenomenon has eluded everyone for hundreds of years but there are a great number of theories." She smiled. "The point is, we do not want the entire world to know of this which is why we have groups such as The clean up crew."

"What of the problem child gang?" Curious, I asked.

"They deal with direct threats, when they arise." Patiently, mom said. "If you want to learn more, ask your father. I must rest now."
